"Scouting Grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 55 | Speed: 45 | Arm: 70 | Field: 50 | Overall: 45  Signed for $300,000 in 2014, Gonzalez struggled in his first taste of pro ball the following year, hitting just .203 over 70 games in the Dominican Summer League. He did anything but struggle in his 2016 U.S. debut, when he paced the Rookie-level Arizona League in both home runs (eight) and slugging percentage (.556) en route to the circuit's MVP Award. Advancing to Class A Short Season Mahoning Valley in 2017, Gonzalez continued to flash his offensive ceiling as a New York-Penn League midseason All-Star.   Physically strong and mature for his age, Gonzalez possesses plus raw power to all fields from the right side of the plate and already understands how to get to it. With that big power comes a longer swing as well as swing-and-miss issues that are exacerbated by an aggressive approach and problems identifying spin. Those weaknesses have led some to worry about whether he will make enough contact to be successful at higher levels. Defensively, Gonzalez has prototypical right-field tools as a good athlete with modest speed and a cannon arm.   With robust raw power as his calling card but concerns about his bat, Gonzalez is the definition of a high-risk prospect at this stage in his career. The potential is there, but he'll need to make many adjustments along the way."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 55 | Power: 50 | Run: 30 | Arm: 50 | Field: 50 | Overall: 45  After exceeding their international bonus pool in 2014-15, the Red Sox had spending limitations the next two periods, but came away with a possible steal for $5,000 in 2015. Castellanos, a Venezuelan, broke into pro ball by batting .326 and leading the Rookie-level Dominican Summer League with 23 doubles. He made his U.S. debut at age 19 last year, hitting .339 in the Rookie-level Gulf Coast League (losing out on the batting title by .001) and getting promoted to Class A to help Greenville win the South Atlantic League title.  Castellanos has barely played at the full-season level but already shows some of the most intriguing offensive potential in the system. He has an advanced approach, focusing on making line-drive contact from gap to gap, while posting an impressive nine percent strikeout rate in his first two pro seasons. Big and physical, he shows home run power during batting practice and should start doing so in games as he continues to add strength.  While most of his value will come from his offense, Castellanos has some defensive versatility. He lacks speed, but has decent range and presents a good target at first base. He has average arm strength and will continue to see action on both outfield corners after doing so in each of his first two seasons."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Curveball: 50 | Changeup: 50 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45  Part of the Cubs' 2013 international spending spree, Moreno has posted one of the system's best ground-ball rates since signing for $650,000 out of Colombia. But he also has had a difficult time remaining on the mound, blowing out his elbow and requiring Tommy John surgery after five pro games. He dazzled with a 1.88 ERA and 55/9 K/BB ratio in the lower levels of the system in his first full season back in 2016, but a sore shoulder limited him to 14 starts and diminished his performance in low Class A last year.  When he's fully healthy, Moreno can generate groundout after groundout with the power sink and the downhill plane on his 92-96 mph fastball. His secondary pitches are more works in progress but show potential. He has feel for his changeup and while his curveball can get slurvy, he's doing better with it after also trying a slider.  Moreno's health history and the effort in his delivery lead to questions about his ability to remain a starter. His walk rate more than tripled from 1.3 per nine innings in 2016 to 4.4 last year, which also doesn't help his cause. He needs innings to refine his repertoire and control, and to prove he can hold up over a full pro season."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 55 | Run: 50 | Arm: 60 | Field: 50 | Overall: 45  The Marlins signed Soto for $310,000 in 2013 out of the Dominican Republic based on his potential at the plate. He offered a taste of his hitting ability and power during his professional debut in the Rookie-level Gulf Coast League the following year, when, at age 17, he tied for second in the league with seven home runs. He rebounded from a torn meniscus in his left knee that had limited him to just 29 games in 2015 to enjoy a healthy '16 campaign in the full-season Class A South Atlantic League. However, that progress was lost as Soto once again fell victim to injury in 2017, when a fractured foot suffered while pursuing a fly ball in Minor League camp required surgery, effectively ending his season before it began.   Though not physically imposing, Soto generates plus raw power from the left side with excellent bat speed, and his short, compact swing has scouts thinking that he'll also hit for average. He can punish good fastballs, but struggles to recognize spin and tries to pull the ball too often, with an aggressive approach that currently results in a fair amount of swing-and-miss and weak contact. Defensively, Soto has prototypical right-field tools with his average speed and plus arm.  Soto may be raw and well behind the development curve, but his offensive ceiling is substantial. He has the makings of a middle-of-the-order hitter if it all clicks, though he's years away from making an impact at the highest level and first will need to prove he can stay on the field."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 40 | Run: 60 | Arm: 50 | Field: 50 | Overall: 45    A Dominican, Mendoza became eligible to sign in July 2013 but didn't find any takers until the Rockies gave him $80,000 in February 2016. He put himself on the prospect map with a spectacular U.S. debut in 2017, hitting .364/.412/.519 and ranking second in the Rookie-level Pioneer League in both batting and steals (25).    Mendoza has a sound left-handed swing and a feel for making line-drive contact. He carries more than his listed 165 pounds and has some strength that could turn into double-digit home run power if he can learn to backspin the ball. He has plus speed and runs the bases aggressively.    Mendoza spent his first two pro seasons at second base, but he lacked fluid actions and had a short arm action. He also topped Pioneer League second basemen with 21 errors in just 55 games in 2017, after which the Rockies moved him to the outfield for this season. With his quickness, he should be able to develop into at least an average defender in the outfield."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 55 | Curveball: 55 | Changeup: 50 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45  The Pirates went over-slot value to land Supak in the supplemental second round in 2014, giving the Texas prep hurler $1 million to forgo his commitment to the University of Houston. He pitched for two seasons in Pittsburgh's system before being shipped to the Brewers with Keon Broxton in December 2015. While the right-hander progressed nicely in Milwaukee's system before breaking out in 2017, when his improved stuff and bat-missing ability led to a dominant early-season showing with Class A Wisconsin followed by a promotion to Class A Advanced Carolina in May.   Supak's fastball typically sits in the low 90s with late life, at times bumping 95 mph, and there should be more velocity to come as he continues to add strength to his projectable frame. He's learned to throw more downhill since being drafted, but needs to be even more consistent at it given his natural fly-ball tendencies. The Brewers laud Supak's feel for spinning the ball, as he shows present feel for locating a potentially above-average curveball, as well as his aptitude for throwing a fading changeup.   Supak's progress in developing his three-pitch mix showed in 2017, as he held hitters to a .213 average while piling up 110 strikeouts over a career-high 113 1/3 frames. Supak still requires quite a bit of physical projection, needs to improve his fastball command and further refine his secondaries, but he could be a durable mid-rotation starter with three Major League average-or-better pitches when all is said and done."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 45 | Run: 50 | Arm: 55 | Field: 55 | Overall: 45  Bannon hit a combined .238 with eight homers in his first two seasons at Xavier before exploding as a junior in 2017, winning Big East Conference player of the year honors after hitting .339 and topping the circuit with 15 homers, 140 total bases and a .633 slugging percentage. He continued to rake after signing for $122,500 as an eighth-round pick, logging a .336/.425/.591 slash line in the Rookie-level Pioneer League. The Dodgers believed he was advanced enough to handle a jump to Class A Advanced to begin his first full pro season.  Despite those gaudy numbers at the plate, Bannon may be more impressive with the glove. He has range to both sides and comes in on balls well, and he possesses soft hands as well as solid arm strength. He could be a plus defender with more consistency, and he's quick enough that Los Angeles is giving him some time at second base this year.  Bannon still has to prove his bat will play at higher levels, but he's off to a good start. His right-handed swing can get long at times and he can be overly pull-conscious, though he does have power to left field and the patience to draw some walks. He's an average runner with nice instincts on the bases."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 55 | Power: 40 | Run: 40 | Arm: 50 | Field: 55 | Overall: 45    Coming out of Florida high school powerhouse Venice High, Longhi decided to forego his commitment to LSU as a talented two-way player when the Red Sox gave him $440,000 in the 30th round of the Draft to become a hitter only. He had made it to Double-A in 2017 when he was sent to the Reds in return for international bonus pool money. Seven games in with his new organization, Longhi's left elbow popped, requiring Tommy John surgery in mid-July.  Longhi had a reputation of being one of the most advanced hitters in Boston's system and he was off to a good start with Cincinnati before he got hurt. He's hit over power, with a patient approach and an ability to make hard contact to all fields. His swing path doesn't lend itself to a ton of power, but he has the bat speed and strength to drive the ball more than he has, and there was a small uptick in power in 2017.     A better athlete than some give him credit for, Longhi has seen time at first and an outfield corner, with more at the former of late. It's tough to be a first baseman only in the Reds system with Joey Votto in the big leagues, so the Reds will go back to mixing it up more frequently with Longhi."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Curveball: 50 | Changeup: 50 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45  After his freshman season at University of San Diego, Olson transferred to Division II Cal Poly Pomona and proceeded to go 12-0 with a 1.73 ERA as a sophomore, then pitched in the Cape Cod League. He was able to make just five starts as a junior, however, with a back injury ending his season. The Reds liked him enough to take him in the 13th round and give him $250,000 to sign. It's taken some time for him to rehab fully from the injury, but he's showing signs of moving in the right direction.  Olson threw just 23 2/3 innings in 2017 as he continued to work his way back, but now that he's fully healthy, his stuff has ticked back up. He's throwing his fastball regularly in the 92-96 mph range with good sink and commands the pitch well. He backs the heater up with a solid curve and changeup as well. He throws strikes with all three pitches and could have above-average control when all is said and done. He gets weak contact and misses some bats along the way.  Olson's biggest key is to show he can stay healthy and be a durable part of a rotation. A full and healthy 2018 season could answer those concerns and send him on the way to being a back-end starter in the big leagues."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 45 | Run: 50 | Arm: 55 | Field: 55 | Overall: 45  Raley had a monster junior season at NCAA Division II Lake Erie (Ohio) in 2016, setting school records for hitting (.424), on-base percentage (.528), slugging (.747) and homers (12). He also eclipsed Ryan Rua as the highest-drafted player in Storm history when the Dodgers took him in the second round. They challenged him with an assignment to high Class A for his first full pro season and he responded by batting .295 with 46 extra-base hits.  Raley has strength and leverage in his 6-foot-3 frame and could develop average power if he adds more loft to his left-handed stroke. For now, he tends to drive balls to the gaps and hit more grounders than he should. An average runner out of the batter's box who picks up speed underway, he's aggressive on the bases.  With his sound instincts and solid arm strength, Raley can get the job done on either outfield corner. He also can fill in as a center fielder and has seen action at first base. Club officials praise his grinder attitude and believe he'll get the most out of his ability."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 55 | Curveball: 50 | Cutter: 50 | Changeup: 55 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45  A key reliever on Texas' 2014 College World Series team as a freshman, Cooper blew out his elbow that fall and missed all of 2015 following Tommy John surgery. He turned down the Nationals as a 34th-rounder after returning as a starter in 2016, then went 32 rounds earlier last year, when he was the Longhorns' ace. The Dodgers thought he showed first-round stuff early in the spring before he tired, and they opted to shut him down for the summer after signing him for a below-slot $867,500 as a redshirt junior.  When he's at full strength, Cooper has a 92-94 mph fastball that reaches 96. His 6-foot-5 frame and overhand delivery create a steep downhill plane that results in swings and misses as well as groundouts. All of his secondary pitches are solid at their best, with his changeup showing more consistency than his curveball and cutter.  Cooper's velocity decreased at the end of his last two college seasons, so he'll have to prove he can hold up over a full year as a pro. His clean delivery and arm action are well suited for starting, though his walk rate did rise in each of his three seasons at Texas. His curveball was his second-best pitch as a freshman but hasn't been as reliable since he got hurt and moved into the rotation."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 40 | Run: 60 | Arm: 50 | Field: 55 | Overall: 45  The kind of player who might not jump out at you after one viewing, Montgomery tends to gain fans who see all of the little things he can do fairly well over a longer period of time. The Angels liked what they saw enough to take the outfielder in the eighth round of the 2016 Draft out of Ohio State and enough to push him rapidly through the system as he reached Double-A in his first full year before finishing the year in the Arizona Fall League. The Tigers liked what they saw enough to make sure they got him in the offseason Ian Kinsler deal.  A left-handed hitter, Montgomery has always had a solid feel to hit to go along with a good knowledge of the strike zone. He draws walks, gets on base and makes consistent hard contact. That leads to some extra-base ability and while he's never going to be a huge power guy, he will run into a few along the way. He's a plus runner, though an inefficient basestealer, and that speed helps him provide solid outfield defense.  Montgomery is more than capable of playing center field, but has played all three spots capably as a pro. That's good, because his profile is that of a productive fourth outfielder who can move wherever he is needed."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 55 | Curveball: 45 | Slider: 45 | Changeup: 55 | Control: 55 | Overall: 45  In 2016, Jorge reached Double-A for the first time, finished among the organization's leaders in ERA and wins and earned a spot on the 40-man roster. For an encore in 2017, the right-hander was once again one of the better pitching prospects in the system numbers-wise and made his big league debut when a spot starter was needed in Minnesota.  That Jorge did not pitch particularly well in the big leagues, or during his time in Triple-A, speaks to an issue about his lack of pure stuff to get upper level hitters out. He's an extreme strike-thrower with a career 2.2 walks per nine ratio in his Minor League career, but there is concern he doesn't have the weapons to miss enough bats in the big leagues. He will throw his fastball anywhere in the 90-95 mph range and the Twins think he could throw harder more consistently if he employed his lower half better and have more extension in his delivery. His changeup is his best next option after his fastball, his slider flashes average and he'll mix in a slow curve to try to keep hitters off-balance.   While still slender, Jorge has proven to be durable, throwing more than 140 innings in each of the past three seasons. However, right triceps soreness forced him to begin 2018 on the disabled list. If he can refine his delivery to find a bit more velocity or tighten up one of his secondary pitches to get it to plus, he can be more than the back-end starter his ceiling appears to be at this point."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 65 | Curveball: 55 | Changeup: 40 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45     After an up-and-down career at Dallas Baptist, Smith still went in the third round of the 2015 Draft to the Tigers, who have long coveted arm strength. Injuries slowed the right-hander's progress early, but he developed into a solid relief prospect who pitched at three levels in '17 while getting traded twice. Detroit sent him to Tampa for Mikie Mahtook in the spring and the Rays shipped Smith to the Mets at the Trade Deadline last July in the Lucas Duda trade.    Smith relies mostly on his fastball-curveball combination in short relief. His heater will sit comfortably in the mid-90s, and he can reach back for more, all from a clean and easy delivery. He'll show an above-average curveball at times with really good snap and spin to it, though not always consistently. Smith doesn't throw his changeup enough, and he'll need to improve his feel for the pitch and use it more in the future, though he did make strides as a strike-thrower in his second full season as he stayed healthy.    Smith joined a group of power relief arms the Mets acquired via trades late last year, giving the organization some depth in that department. He has all the ingredients to be an effective short reliever, with a ceiling of a future setup man."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 55 | Curveball: 50 | Slider: 55 | Changeup: 50 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45    Fry missed his entire first year and most of his second at Oregon State following Tommy John surgery, then returned in 2014 to toss a no-hitter and win the Pacific-12 Conference pitcher of the year award. The White Sox thought he could reach the big leagues quickly after drafting him in the third round that spring and he did, requiring just 107 innings in the Minors. However, he had to have his elbow reconstructed a second time and moved from the rotation to the bullpen before arriving in Chicago last September.    As a starter, Fry was a finesse left-hander whose solid control was his best attribute. Since becoming a reliever he has added about three mph to his fastball, which now sits at 92-94 mph and induces a lot of grounders. His secondary pitches gained some power as well, and there are times when his slider/cutter is his most effective offering.    Fry also throws a curveball that he sometimes has trouble landing in the strike zone, as well as a changeup he employs to keep right-handers honest. His control and command weren't as sharp last year when he came back from his second Tommy John surgery, and big league hitters took advantage of that deficiency in September. If he can do a better job of locating his pitches, he could become a seventh-inning option for the White Sox."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Slider: 50 | Changeup: 50 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45  Six years after signing for $13,000 out of Venezuela in 2010, Machado still hadn't reached full-season ball. Tommy John surgery that sidelined him for all of 2015 didn't help, but his 5-15, 4.91 record in five seasons in Rookie leagues didn't exactly scream success. His stock changed dramatically in 2017, however, which he began in high Class A and ended with two appearances in Kansas City.  Machado sits at 92-95 mph and tops out at 97 with riding life on his four-seam fastball. His changeup shows flashes of becoming a plus pitch but also can get too firm at times and couldn't prevent left-handers from batting .300/.365/.525 against him last year. His mid-80s slider features more velocity than tilt and got hammered during his brief time in the big leagues, when he surrendered nine runs and got 11 outs.  Machado's walk rate dropped from 4.7 per nine innings before he had his elbow reconstructed to 2.6 in the first two years afterward. While he's providing more strikes, his command lags behind his control and his delivery lacks deception, so he's fairly hittable. Though he fared well as a starter in Double-A last year, his inconsistencies and the fact that he never has pitched more than 77 innings in a season point to a likely future as a reliever."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 55 | Power: 30 | Run: 65 | Arm: 45 | Field: 55 | Overall: 45  Tilson performed as well as any player at the 2010 Area Code Games, which led the Cardinals to take him in the second round and pay him an over-slot $1,275,000 the following year. He steadily advanced to Triple-A by 2016 and immediately joined the White Sox after St. Louis traded him for Zach Duke that July, singling in his first at-bat but tearing his left hamstring later in the game and requiring season-ending surgery. Chicago expected him to be its center fielder and leadoff man in 2017, but a stress reaction in his right foot and a stress fracture in his right ankle caused him to miss the entire regular season.  Tilson fits the classic leadoff profile, using a compact left-handed swing and balanced approach to make regular line-drive contact and get on base. Once there, he has the well above-average speed to swipe bases and make things happen. Though he doesn't have much power, he has put on 20 pounds since turning pro and can sting some balls to the gaps.  His quickness also plays well in center field, where he can range from gap to gap. His fringy arm is playable in center and left but limits his usefulness in right field. Now 25 after losing a year and a half to injuries, he still has time to win an everyday job in Chicago."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 50 | Run: 55 | Arm: 50 | Field: 50 | Overall: 45  Norwood is best remembered for hitting the game-winning home run that propelled Vanderbilt to its first College World Series title in 2014. He wasn't drafted in June, but performed well during the summer in the Cape Cod League before signing with the Marlins for $275,000. He's since made a steady climb through the Marlins' system, highlighted by an All-Star campaign in the Double-A Southern League in 2017 during which he established career highs in most offensive categories.  Norwood generates big pull-side raw power with his strong core and quick bat. He sells out for it too often, though, pulling off the ball with a long swing that limits his use of the opposite field and results in too many strikeouts. He's developed better feel for recognizing and hitting breaking balls while climbing the latter, in turn boosting his on-base skills, and there's never been much about Norwood's ability to turn around quality velocity.   An above-average runner, Norwood's speed translates better in the outfield than on the basepaths. He's capable of playing center field in a pinch but profiles better in right field, where he's spent much of his pro career. Norwood's right-handed power could make him an option off the bench in the big leagues, but he'll first need to show he can make adjustments against upper-level pitchers."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 55 | Curveball: 55 | Cutter: 50 | Changeup: 50 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45  Shepherd set a Kentucky high school record with a 46-inning scoreless streak as a sophomore, missed his junior season following Tommy John surgery and then re-emerged as the state's best prep prospect as a senior in 2011. He split time between the rotation and bullpen during three college seasons at Kentucky, then became a full-time reliever after the Red Sox made him a 13th-round choice in 2014. After his successful winter starting in the Mexican Pacific League, Boston will keep him in the role this year.  Shepherd used four pitches as a reliever, so he has more than enough options as a starter. He has a pair of solid offerings in a 91-93 mph fastball that tops out at 95 with some run and sink, and a curveball with good depth. He also uses a cutter/slider and a tumbling changeup, both of which are average.  Though he doesn't have a plus pitch, Shepherd still averaged 9.1 strikeouts per nine innings in his first four pro seasons. He mixes his pitches well, keeps them down in the strike zone and enjoys equal success against left-handers and right-handers. The knock on him as a starter was his inability to maintain his stuff over several innings, but he did a better job of that in Mexico."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 55 | Power: 40 | Run: 50 | Arm: 40 | Field: 45 | Overall: 45  Filia emerged as UCLA's leading postseason hitter during the team's 2013 College World Series championship run, only to miss all of the next two seasons. He lost 2014 after injuring his right (throwing) shoulder and requiring labrum surgery, then he was suspended for all of '15 after he plagiarized part of a paper for a philosophy class. Filia returned to the Bruins in 2016 and then signed for $1,000 as a 20th-round pick at age 24, making him one of the oldest players in the 2016 Draft. After excelling in his first full season in the Class A Advanced California League and then again in the Arizona Fall League, Filia was suspended for the first 50 games of the 2018 season following his second positive test for a drug of abuse in January.  Filia has one of the more advanced approaches among Minor League hitters, with outstanding pitch and zone recognition, plus bat-to-ball skills and innate feel to hit from line to line. He led the Northwest League in hitting (.362) and on-base percentage (.450) and won the short-season circuit's MVP in his pro debut, and then ranked first in the California League in OBP (.407) and third in batting (.326) in his sophomore campaign. He encored with standout performance in the Arizona Fall League, where he saw time at both corner outfield positions as well as first base.  Pure hitting ability and on-base skills -- he accrued 20 more walks than strikeouts in 2017 -- are Filia's calling cards to the Major Leagues, as he otherwise possesses average-at-best tools. But while it may be easy to peg him as a future fourth or fifth outfielder, there's something to be said about Filia's track record of surpassing expectations."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 55 | Slider: 55 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45    Sherriff has definitely defied the odds. The left-hander started out as a 28th-round Draft pick back in 2011 out of Glendale Community College. Devoloped initially as a starter, he moved to the bullpen in 2014 and started putting up numbers at the upper levels without much fanfare, earning Pacific Coast League All-Star honors in 2016 and 17. Ignored in the Rule 5 Draft, Sherriff finally got added to the roster and called up to the big leagues for the first time in August of last year.    It was an opportunity well-earned and Sherriff largely did what he was supposed to do, keeping left-handed hitters to a .080 batting average over 25 at-bats. That should come as no surprise, given he'd kept lefties to averages under .200 in Triple-A the last two seasons. Sherriff comes at hitters with a funky arm angle that brings in fastballs up to 93-94 mph and thrown with a ton of sink that gets a lot of groundball outs. He complements that with a very good slider, which when coming from his lower arm slot, is death to lefties.    This has the chance to be one of those outstanding player development stories of perseverance. As long as he keeps throwing his fastball-slider combination for strikes, and he has for most of his career, there's no reason to believe he can' be a big league reliever for many years to come."

mi_blurb: "Age 21, 11th round pick in 2017 from North Carolina State; hit stunning .370/.431/.549 in 162 at-bats in New York-Penn League, then more human .270/.286/.419 in 74 at-bats in Midwest League; must tighten strike zone but has a chance to hit for average with gap power; outstanding defensive third baseman with superior range, reliability, and instincts; sleeper prospect in a deep system where it is hard to get noticed; ETA 2022."
mlbp_blurb: "Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 40 | Run: 40 | Arm: 55| Field: 55 | Overall: 45  Mendoza headed to North Carolina State from Sarasota, Fla. as a two-way player. When his pitching career fizzled after his freshman year, he focused on his bat and his play at third, and after a strong sophomore season and standout Cape Cod League campaign over the summer, he looked to be an interesting college bat for the 2017 Draft class. Struggles during his junior year led to a slide to the 11th round, which he promptly forgot during his pro debut, when he won the New York-Penn League batting title.  In his brief career, Mendoza has shown an innate ability to barrel up the baseball from the right side of the plate with a line drive approach. He can drive the ball to all fields, albeit without over-the-fence power, as he is much more focused on contact. Mendoza has the chance to be a plus defender at the hot corner, with good hands, footwork and a strong arm.  Without the requisite power, Mendoza doesn't currently truly fit the third base profile. If that develops in the future, he could be the kind of run producer teams covet at the hot corner."

mi_blurb: "Age 21, second round pick in 2014, posted 3.17 ERA with 139/41 K/BB in 136 innings in Low-A/High-A, 123 hits; although the stats were solid scouting reports have cooled rapidly, with fastball dipping into 80s and unexciting secondary stuff; hes still whiffing hitters at a good clip but skepticism that this will continue at higher levels has increased; if he moves up to Double-A and keeps pitching well, bump this grade up a notch. ETA late 2019."
mlbp_blurb: "Scouting grades: Fastball: 50 | Slider: 50 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45  Some pitching prospects wow with pure stuff, missing bats with premium velocity. Then there are the pitchers like Reed, the D-Backs' 2014 second-rounder who hit a little hiccup in the second half of 2016 with a minor shoulder issue, but righted the ship the next season. The southpaw used his pitchability and deception to have a much more complete season, finishing third in the organization in ERA and fourth in strikeouts.    Reed gets a lot of swings and misses in the strike zone with his fastball, leading to a career 9.8 K/9 rate. But he doesn't do it with velocity; his fastball registers as just average on the radar gun. He hides the ball well, with the ball seemingly coming out of his jersey at times, so hitters don't get comfortable swings at it. His slider will flash above-average at times, then it will back up and come in fringy. He's gotten more consistent in landing it for strikes and he'll mix in a decent changeup with some fade as well.    Reed's control has improved over time, but his overall command will have to get better as he moves up the ladder. Keeping the ball down in the zone, and limiting the home runs, will be key as he attacks the upper levels of the D-backs' system."

mi_blurb: "Age 23, fourth round pick in 2016 from University of Florida; posted 3.45 ERA with 156/48 K/BB in 136 innings in Low-A, 114 hits; fastball reported anywhere between 88 and 95 MPH, report I had from the Midwest League had him sitting at 91, but heater playing up due to effective mixing with plus slider and decent change-up; also drew positive notice for mound presence, work ethic; he didnt pitch much in college due to injuries so there could be untapped possibilities here; I wrote him up so you would notice him. ETA 2020."
mlbp_blurb: "Scouting Grades: Fastball: 50 | Slider: 50 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45    Moss barely pitched in college with the University of Florida, first because of Tommy John surgery that kept him out for two years and then because he couldn't break through a ridiculously deep Gators pitching staff in 2016. He got on the mound enough, including a rare start in the SEC Tournament, for the Reds to take a chance and select him in the fourth round of that June's Draft.     Moss's assignment to the Midwest League in 2017 may have seemed a bit conservative for a college arm, but given his lack of mound time and injury history, the goal was to keep him healthy and give him a full season's workload without the pressure of promotion. Mission accomplished, as Moss ended up leading the system in wins while finishing second in strikeouts and sixth in ERA. Moss does it with largely average stuff, but uses his 6-foot-5 frame well, with his 91-92 mph fastball getting on hitters quickly because of excellent extension. Opponents don't get good looks at his slider or improving changeup, either, as deception is a key part of his game.    The Reds think there's more in the tank as Moss logs more innings. With a full, successful year under his belt, it will be interesting to see what kind of step forward the big lefty can take in reaching his back-end starter ceiling."

mi_blurb: "Age 24, third round pick in 2014 from Fresno State University, hit .302/.382/.527 with 23 homers, 45 walks, 81 strikeout in 414 at-bats between Double-A and Triple-A; hit .205/.276/.385 with three homers, six walks, 22 strikeouts in 78 major league at-bats; power is real but looks to have contact issues in the majors, although the upside as a hitter is enough to earn more chances; tools fit best in left field; he may be underestimated here; ETA 2018."
mlbp_blurb: "Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 50 | Run: 45 | Arm: 50 | Field: 45 | Overall: 45  A third round pick out of Fresno State in 2014, Luplow, a former college outfield mate of the Yankees' Aaron Judge, had put in a pair of solid, but relatively nondescript full seasons in the lower levels of the Pirates system over his first two full years of pro ball. He surprised many when he moved to Double-A in 2017 and hit his way first to Triple-A and then to the big leagues, leading the organization in home runs and finishing second in batting average along the way.  Luplow had always shown glimpses of power, but took a big step forward in turning his extra-base ability into over-the-fence pop in 2017. He can drive the ball to all fields and his continued improvements in terms of pitch recognition and plate discipline have made him a better all-around hitter. He'll have to trust that approach and his bat-to-ball skills to hit more consistently at the big league level. While he tried to play third for a season in 2015, he has settled into the outfield corners, where he has shown he is a capable defender.  Luplow still looks like a fourth outfielder type when all is said and done. But he's ready for that role now and given that he's exceeded expectations in many ways, he could hit his way into more at-bats in Pittsburgh."

mi_blurb: "Age 26, third round pick in 2012 from University of Florida; career slowed by nagging injuries and off-field issues but took huge step forward in 2017, posting 2.92 ERA with 46/26 K/BB in 49 innings in Double-A/Triple-A then 0.52 ERA in 17 major league innings with 14/2 K/BB; fastball up to 93-96 MPH, slider and change-up; stuff profiles well in bullpen if he throws strikes like he did in the majors; ETA 2018."
mlbp_blurb: "Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Slider: 45 | Changeup: 55 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45  The Red Sox grabbed two Florida two-way players in the 2012 Draft, Brian Johnson in the first round and Maddox in the third. The latter hit 17 homers as a Gators freshman but offers more upside on the mound. After he recorded a 5.05 ERA in his first four pro seasons, he added velocity in 2016 and made his big league debut last year, allowing one run in 17 1/3 innings to earn a spot on Boston's playoff roster. Maddox began the 2018 season on the Red Sox's disabled list with a shoulder strain.  Maddox's four-seam fastball averaged 95 mph in his first taste of the Majors and usually ranges from 92-97 mph. He'll throw it up in the strike zone to set up his changeup, a mid-80s weapon with splitter action that also can be a plus pitch at times. He'll keep hitters off balance by mixing in an occasional mid-80s slider that shows some flashes of becoming an average offering.  Maddox's control has slipped a bit as he has started throwing harder, and he has to be careful with his location because his reliance on four-seamers has made him a fly-ball pitcher. While he may not be a high-leverage reliever, he made a good first impression in Boston and could be a seventh-inning option."

mlbd_blurb: "Scouting grades: Hit: 40 | Power: 55 | Run: 45 | Arm: 60 | Field: 50 | Overall: 45  TNXL Baseball Academy was started a few years ago in Florida as a place for high-level high school level players to focus more of their day on baseball, while taking care of classwork online through the Florida Virtual School. Cabell has been one of the better products of the academy to date, with some serious upside, though it does not come without risk.  There is no question that Cabell looks the part of an impactful offensive player and has the bat skills to go along with it. He has tremendous raw power with the ability to drive the ball with the kind of different sound you hear from some hitters when he makes contact. With that power, however, comes some considerable swing and miss issues, as scouts see a grooved swing. It goes a long way when the ball is thrown in that groove, but he doesn't always adjust when it's not.   A fringy rurnner, Cabell is a capable outfielder with a very strong arm, and he gets high marks for his makeup. If a team believes he can make enough contact to tap into that power, it could see him as a future run-producing right fielder and take him early enough to keep him from heading to LSU."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Slider: 50 | Changeup: 50 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45  After getting shelled by Virginia Military in his first 2018 start, Hill flirted with no-hitters against Charleston Southern and Clemson in his next two outings while striking out 14 each time. That sent his Draft stock soaring, though he hasn't been as sharp since and missed a start in March with shoulder tendinitis. He still has a chance to become the fourth South Carolina right-hander selected in the top three rounds in the last three Drafts, following Clarke Schmidt, Wil Crowe and Braden Webb.  Hill's best pitch is his fastball, which sits around 91-93 mph and peaks at 95. He uses his 6-foot-5 frame to create good plane and extension, and has some crossfire in his delivery that imparts running life on his heater. His changeup has been more reliable than his slider this spring, with each showing signs of becoming a solid offering when at their best.  Hill is more physical than athletic, and he sometimes struggles to keep his delivery together and locate his pitches where he wants. If he can do a better job of maintaining his velocity into the later innings, improving the consistency of his secondary offerings and commanding his stuff, he could be a No. 3 starter. If not, he might be more of a sixth- or seventh-inning reliever because he lacks an overpowering fastball or a dynamic second pitch."

mlbp_blurb: "Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 35 | Run: 50 | Arm: 55 | Field: 55 | Overall: 45    Jimenez was already well known for his exploits on the field as a Panamanian amateur when he signed with the Blue Jays for $825,000 in July 2017. He represented his country at the 12U World Cup in Taiwan in 2013, the COPABE 14U Championship in '15 and the COPABE 16U Championship the following year.    Jimenez is a sum-of-all parts player who stands out more for his all-around game than any specific tools. He makes consistent contact from the right side of the plate with a swing that's direct to the ball and fuels his middle-away approach. He has present pop to the gaps and could grow into some over-the-fence power, though it will never be a major part of his game.    Defensively, Jimenez, an average runner, is solid if unspectacular at shortstop, where he's an instinctual player who makes all the routine plays and is fundamentally sound. While not explosive in his actions, Jimenez is athletic and earns praise from club officials for his intuitiveness and positioning."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Curveball: 55 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45  If it seems like the Angels are collecting intriguing, young pitching prospects courtesy of their efforts on the international amateur market, looks are not deceiving. Aquino, a 6-foot-6 right-hander signed in December 2016, might have as much ceiling as any of them, though he also might have the furthest to go to get there.  The Angels compare Aquino's fastball-curve combination with that of Jose Soriano in terms of future impact and he used it to pitch his way from the Dominican Summer League to a brief taste of pro ball in the United States in the rookie-level Arizona League. When Aquino signed, he was 90-91 mph with his fastball, but thanks to some big strength gains, he was touching 96 mph and sitting 93-94 mph last fall at instructs, thrown with plus spin and riding life up in the zone. His curve already flashes plus with a very high spin rate, while his changeup will flash average, though it needs work.  Aquino doesn't have as athletic a delivery as Soriano, and will need to continue to work to repeat it effectively. If he can get more consistent with his direction to the plate, his command should get better, as should his already impressive raw stuff."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 50 | Slider: 50 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45    Madero first signed with the D-backs out of Venezuela for $160,000 in October 2013 at age 16 and made his pro debut in the Dominican Summer League the following summer. His transition to the United States went smoothly enough in the rookie-level Arizona League in 2015, though a bump to the Pioneer League in 2016 didn't go as well. He had pitched his way to the short-season Northwest League in 2017, when he was sent to the Angels in the David Hernandez deal right at the Trade Deadline. and finished with six starts in the full-season Midwest League.    Now 21, Madero has made slow and steady progress and still has some projection to his lanky 6-foot-3 frame. His fastball is up to 93 mph, sitting in the 90- to 91-mph range with decent movement, with decent movement, and he keeps the ball down, getting both swings and misses and ground-ball outs. His breaking ball is slurvy at times, but at its best, it looks like an above-average slider that serves as his out pitch. He's starting to use his changeup more frequently.    Loose and athletic, Madero throws strikes and consistently gets excellent extension on his delivery. Some see a resemblance to former Angel Francisco Rodriguez, goggles and all, with a ceiling as a back-end starter."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 55 | Power: 35 | Run: 45 | Arm: 50 | Field: 45 | Overall: 45  The Twins were very excited to see what Arreaz, who signed out of Venezuela back in 2013, was going to do for an encore in 2017 after winning the Midwest League batting title in 2016, then finishing seventh as a 19-year-old in the Venezuelan Winter League. Three games in to his 2017 season, however, Arreaz tore his ACL, ending his year.  Arreaz's carrying tool is definitely his bat and he could be a plus hitter when all is said and done. He posts extreme contact rates with outstanding plate discipline, using the opposite field a lot. He competes in the box as well as anyone in the system and doesn't give up at-bats, though he could still learn how to drive certain pitches in hitter's counts more effectively. He's never been overly athletic, and the knee issue won't help in that regard, so there is some question as to what position he'll ultimately call home. He has decent hands for second and he could also see time in left field.  The hope is for Arreaz to return to action in mid-May and let him get acclimated back to the pro game. His bat will play, so it's just a matter of finding at-bats for him on the field, perhaps at both positions."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Curveball: 55 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45  The Giants drafted Nelson as a pitcher out of Rutherford High (Panama City, Fla.) in the 31st round in 2014, but he opted instead to stay home and play both ways at Gulf Coast State (Fla.) CC. He won 13 games and hit 19 homers in two years with the Commodores before signing with the Yankees for a below-slot $350,000 in 2016's fourth round. Though he led the low Class A South Atlantic League with 12 losses in his first full pro season, he showed progress by posting a 3.47 ERA in his final starts after getting lit up for a 6.34 ERA in his first nine.  Nelson's best pitch is a 92-97 mph fastball with ground-ball-inducing sink. His hard curveball could give him a second plus offering if he gets more consistent with it. He's in the early stages of refining a changeup to combat left-handers after rarely using it as an amateur.  Strong and athletic, Nelson would have continued as a two-way player had he transferred to Florida rather than turning pro. He's still figuring out how to repeat his delivery on a regular basis, though he did cut his walk rate from 9.3 per nine innings in his 2016 debut to 4.5 last year. Though New York will continue to develop him as a starter for now, there's a good chance that he'll wind up as a power reliever."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 55 | Curveball: 55 | Changeup: 50 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45  The Cubs gave seven-figure bonuses to three high school pitchers in the 2014 Draft: $1.1 million to Carson Sands in the fourth round, $1 million to Steele in the fifth and $1.5 million to since-traded Dylan Cease in the sixth. All three have had elbow surgery since turning pro, with Steele succumbing to Tommy John surgery last August. He had been enjoying his best pro season, ranking second in the Carolina League with a 2.92 ERA when he blew out his elbow.  Steele began to make the transition from thrower to pitcher in 2017. He did a better job of commanding his fastball, which ranges from 91-97 mph with groundout-inducing sink. He got more consistent depth and missed more bats with his curveball, and he also showed more trust in his changeup.  Steele also made progress with his control and command, though both need further improvement. More athletic than physical, he started to create hope that he could become a mid-rotation starter. Chicago plans to exercise patience with his comeback, so he probably won't pitch during the 2018 regular season."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 55 | Curveball: 60 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45  The Cubs took a 38th-round flyer on Brown in the 2013 Draft, knowing that he likely would honor his commitment to the University of Kentucky. He did just that, but pitched to uneven results during his three seasons with the Wildcats while working as both a starter and a reliever. Intrigued by Brown's untapped potential, the Brewers made him their third-round pick in 2016, signing him for a shade over $400,000. After reaching Class A Wisconsin in his pro debut, Brown excelled in his return to the Midwest League in 2017 and received a late-season promotion to Class A Advanced Carolina, where he put a bow on his first full season with four solid outings.   Brown has made strides as a professional in developing and locating his solid three-pitch mix. He pitches with a 92-95 mph fastball to both sides of the plate and did a better job holding that velocity deep into games in his first full season. He's adept at manipulating the pitch, too, as he'll turn it over to create sinking action at times while reaching back for extra velo with his four-seamer as dictated by the situation. His curveball, though currently underused, is a plus pitch, and he also has feel for a promising changeup that contrasts nicely against his heater.   Brown's detractors believe that he'll end up in the bullpen on account of his high-effort delivery. The Brewers, however, believe he can stick as a starter, and they were impressed with his intensity on the mound and ability to improve the deeper he worked into games. Should that not happen, Brown's fastball-curveball combo and deceptive delivery could make him a late-inning weapon."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Slider: 55 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45  Coonrod caught the attention of scouts when he hit 98 mph as a freshman in Southern Illinois, but he went just 8-17 in three seasons with the Salukis and lasted five rounds in the 2014 Draft. He recorded a 2.82 ERA in his first two full seasons as a pro starter, but struggled in a return to Double-A last year and moved to the bullpen in August. He made just six relief appearances before blowing out his elbow and having Tommy John surgery that will sideline him for the 2018 season.  After working at 92-95 mph with sink on his fastball as a starter, Coonrod flashed upper-90s heat in his brief foray as a reliever last year. His mid-80s slider/cutter should play as a plus pitch more consistently in shorter stints. He has made progress with a sinking changeup, though it may never be more than an average offering and he won't use it much coming out of the bullpen.  Though the Giants have helped Coonrod calm down his delivery since college, his walk rate has risen at every level as he has climbed through the Minors. He still could project as a No. 4 starter if he could improve his changeup and his command, but banking on his pair of power pitches and his competitiveness as a reliever is more realistic."

mi_blurb: "Age 26, from Dominican Republic, earned spot on 40-man roster with excellent season in high minors, 1.79 ERA with 65/19 K/BB in 65 innings, 51 hits; middle relief profile with fastball around 90 but plays up due to plus slider and ability to throw strikes; persistent track record of reverse platoon splits is a point of interest. ETA 2018."
mlbp_blurb: "Scouting grades: Fastball: 55 | Curveball: 55 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45  Signed out of the Dominican Republic in 2010, Suero rewarded the Nationals for their patience with a breakout performance in his eighth professional season. Making 54 appearances between Double-A Harrisburg and Triple-A Syracuse, Suero recorded 20 saves, 10 at each level, while pitching to a 1.76 ERA and .209 opponents' average. It netted him honors as the Nationals' Minor League Pitcher of the Year, and they added him to the 40-man roster during the offseason.   A raw thrower with little feel for the zone early in his career, Suero has since learned to harness and refine his stuff. He works with a 92-94 mph fastball that has natural cutting action and he locates to both sides of the plate, though it can get flat at times. He complements his heater with an above-average curveball and changeup that he made strides with in 2017. Suero's command leaves something to be desired even though his control has improved in each full-season campaign.   The Nationals love Suero's fearlessness on the mound and cite him gaining confidence as a key to his recent progress. While the stuff might not be good enough for him to close games in the big leagues, Suero, with his strong track record against right-handed hitters, should have no trouble carving out a late-inning role."

mlbd_blurb: "Scouting grades: Fastball: 65 | Slider: 55 | Changeup: 50 | Control: 40 | Overall: 45  One of the best high school pitching prospects ever to come out of Delaware, Bilous missed his entire senior season following Tommy John surgery but still got offered $600,000 by the Dodgers after they took him in the 29th round of the 2015 Draft. He contributed to Coastal Carolina's 2016 College World Series championship as a freshman and unquestionably has a first-round arm. Yet he has battled the strike zone throughout three years with the Chanticleers and two summers in the Cape Cod League, making it unclear how high he'll get picked this June.  Bilous has one of the best pure fastballs among college starters, sitting at 92-95 mph and topping out at 97 with sink. In shorter stints on the Cape last summer, he reached 99. His slider combines mid-80s power and late bite, serving as a wipeout pitch at its best, and he can flash a plus changeup with fade as well.  Bilous is athletic but has a long arm action in the back of his delivery that hampers him from repeating his release point and keeping his mechanics in sync. He has averaged at least seven walks per nine innings in each of his three college seasons and may never have more than fringy control. He's probably best suited for the bullpen and has the stuff to handle a high-leverage role if he can find the plate."

mlbp_blurb: "Scouting grades: Fastball: 55 | Curveball: 55 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45  Corry divided his time between two sports as a Utah high schooler, earning all-state honors as a safety in football but also tearing the anterior cruciate ligament in his knee on the gridiron in the fall of 2015. He still became the state's highest-drafted prepster since 2005 Cubs first-rounder Mark Pawelek, signing for a well over-slot $1 million in the third round last June. He's the type of raw mound prospect whom the Giants excel at polishing.  Corry elicits some Matt Moore comparisons because he'll showcase a plus fastball and curveball on his best days. He currently pitches at 90-92 mph with nice running action on his fastball, and he already has touched 96 and should gain more consistent velocity as he gets stronger. He actually commands his upper-70s curve better than his heater but currently struggles to get ahead in the count to set up his breaker.  Though his changeup is in its nascent stages, Corry maintains his arm speed when he throws it. Learning to locate his fastball is No. 1 on his to-do list, and while he has the athleticism to make it happen, he also has a lot of effort in his delivery. He could wind up as a reliever in the long run but San Francisco will give him plenty of time to make it as a starter."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 65 | Curveball: 55 | Slider: 55 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 40 | Overall: 45  Cave battled the strike zone in two years at Florida International before boosting his stock by leading the Cape Cod League with 10 saves and reaching 98 mph with his fastball during the summer of 2016. He decided to transfer to NCAA Division II power Tampa, where he continued to struggle to harness his power arsenal. That continued after the Giants signed him for $417,200 in the fourth round last June.  Cave usually works with a 94-96 mph fastball that features armside run as a reliever and with a little less velocity when he starts. He also can miss bats with a pair of breaking balls, a low-80s curveball with good depth and an upper-80s slider/cutter, though he can't always land them in the strike zone. He also uses a changeup that might give him a decent offspeed pitch if he uses it more often.  Though San Francisco drafted Cave with the idea of trying to develop him as a starter, club officials concede that his never-ending search for command means he'll likely be a reliever. He has cleaned up his delivery some since high school but it still contains a lot of effort and he has difficulty keeping it in sync. Coming out of the bullpen, he'd have late-inning upside if he could throw enough strikes."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 55 | Curveball: 50 | Slider: 50 | Changeup: 50 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45    An above-slot $375,000 signing as a 12th-rounder in 2013, Clifton won pitcher of the year accolades from both the Cubs and the high Class A Carolina League in 2016. He entered last year as the best mound prospect in the upper levels of the system, but returning nearby where he grew up to pitch for Double-A Tennessee proved to be too much of a distraction. He got hammered to the tune of a 7.99 ERA during the final three months, earning a mandate from club officials to get stronger mentally and physically.    During his breakout 2016 season, Clifton operated with a 91-94 mph fastball that touched 97, flashed a plus curveball and improved his changeup. Last year, he lost weight and his stuff regressed, with his fastball dropping into the upper 80s and his curveball deserting him. He tried to rely more on a slurvy slider without success and his changeup also lacked effectiveness.    Control and command never were Clifton's strong suits and they also took a step back in 2017. He has toned down his delivery since entering pro ball but it still some features some effort, so there long have been questions whether he'd be better suited for relief work. He moved near the Cubs' training base in Arizona so he could better prepare for 2018."

mlbd_blurb: "Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Curveball: 50 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45  There is no question that Noah Naylor is the top prospect from Canada in this year's Draft class, separating himself from the pack. Cerantola is No. 2, and the top pitching prospect north of the border, with interested teams looking at his upside potential more than what he brings to the table now.    Cerantola's now stuff isn't bad, it's just raw. He was up to 93 mph with his fastball this spring and presently sits in the 90-91 mph range. With a 6-foot-6 frame that should take on good weight and strength, it's easy to dream on more velocity in the future. His secondary stuff needs work, but he'll show a solid mid-70s curveball at times with good depth at times and has shown some feel for his changeup. He does use his size well and throws downhill. A solid athlete, he repeats his delivery which should help him improve his control.    Canada has produced some very good pitching talent over the years, most recently in the first round with Mike Soroka in 2015 and last year with second-rounder Landon Leach. Cerantola isn't quite in that neck of the woods, but there's enough ceiling to perhaps entice a team to sign him away from his commitment to Mississippi State."

mi_blurb: "Age 17, signed out of Venezuela in 2017 for $1,225,000; hasnt played yet; scouting reports credit him as a slick-fielding shortstop and a switch-hitter with above-average game speed and good strike zone judgment; makeup is also a reported positive; and yes we need to see him play, so grading is problematic; ETA 2023."
mlbp_blurb: "Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 40 | Run: 50 | Arm: 60 | Field: 55 | Overall: 45  As the son of Minor League catcher Juan Querecuto and younger brother of Juniel Querecuto, who reached the Majors with the Rays in 2016, the young Venezuelan shortstop has certainly grown up around the game. The No. 26 prospect on MLB Pipeline's list of the Top 30 international prospects for the 2017-18 period, he signed for $1.225 million on July 2.  Querecuto is a confident prospect with good plate discipline and good instincts on both sides of the ball. The teen has showed a mature approach, good bat speed and the ability to hit the ball to all fields. Scouts believe he'll add some power as he grows into his projectable frame, albeit mostly to the gaps rather than true over-the-fence pop.   Defensively, Querecuto's plus arm strength is more than enough for him to remain at shortstop, where he stands out for his clean actions, soft hands and overall feel for the position. His remaining physical projection could ultimately force him to third base, a position he has the requisite tools for, though it also would place greater pressure on his offensive development."

mi_blurb: "Age 20, 22nd round pick in 2016 from high school in Long Island, New York; posted 2.77 ERA with 72/15 K/BB in 65 innings, 58 hits in New York-Penn League; tall and skinny, listed 6-10, 205 and some say hes taller than that; mechanics are very consistent for his age leading to plus command/control; fastball 87-89, may pick up as he fills out; both slider and change-up are mediocre but hes intimidating and deceptive enough to overmatch the NY-P since he can throw strikes; long way off but interesting; ETA 2022."
mlbp_blurb: "Scouting Grades: Fastball: 55 | Slider: 50 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45  From a town known as Oyster Bay, Long Island, rode a pitcher with potential for a three-pitch mix. His age, and his size, made the Phillies roll the dice, taking Young in the 22nd round of the 2016 Draft and go over pick value to sign him away from attending Hofstra. He pitched well in his brief summer debut and then pitched exceptionally well in the New York-Penn League in 2017.  Young is a 6-foot-10 southpaw, but unlike with many pitchers that big, and that young, he has tremendous control of his body. That allows him to repeat a good, solid delivery and fill the strike zone with all three of his pitches. His fastball sits average velocity-wise right now, but it plays up because of his extension and his ability to command it, and it's easy to see more in the tank. He throws what will be at least an average slider and he shows some feel for a changeup, though that's behind his other two offerings. It's been a small sample size so far, but in his first 92 professional innings, Young has walked just 1.7 per nine.  The Phillies knew it would be a longer process of getting the tall, lanky high schooler up to speed, and to his credit, Young has been very committed to the program, spending extra time in Clearwater working on gaining strength and his pitching craft. He could take a nice step forward in 2018."

mi_blurb: "Age 20, signed by Seattle Mariners out of Dominican Republic in 2014, traded to Yankees for Ben Gamel; posted 2.90 ERA in 62 innings in NY-P with 53/25 K/BB, 42 hits, zero homers; fastball 90-94 with a chance for more due to projectable build, change-up is very advanced for his age and flashes a good curve, seems like a good candidate to step forward in 2018. ETA 2021."
mlbp_blurb: "Scouting grades: Fastball: 55 | Curveball: 50 | Changeup: 50 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45  Signed for $175,000 out of the Dominican Republic by the Mariners in 2014, De Paula pitched well in two seasons of Rookie ball before coming to the Yankees along with fellow right-hander Jio Orozco in an August 2016 trade for Ben Gamel. He was one of the best pitchers on a loaded Staten Island staff in 2017, ranking second in the short-season New York-Penn League in opponent average (.191).  De Paula could have three solid or better pitches once he's fully developed. He shows the aptitude to move his 90-95 mph fastball around the strike zone, and he could throw significantly harder once he fills out his skinny 6-foot-3 frame. He already has added 5-7 mph to his heater since signing.  De Paula also displays the ability to spin a curveball and deceive hitters with his changeup. His secondary pitches and his control lack consistency, as they do with most young pitchers, but the ingredients are there for a No. 4 or 5 starter. If his fastball takes off as he matures physically, he could be more than that."

mlbd_blurb: "Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Curveball: 50 | Changeup: 40 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45  In a relatively down year in Southern California, Cole Winn has separated himself as clearly the best high school arm in the region. While there's quite a bit separating the pair, Champlain is generally thought to be No. 2 and is all about projection and future potential.    Champlain does have a big fastball now and a 6-foot-4 frame that could add strength, making it easy to dream on move velocity to come. His fastball sits in the low 90s, has touched higher at times, with some good life down in the zone. He has good feel for his breaking ball, a curve that should be a least an average secondary pitch for him. His changeup is very much a work in progress and it's not a pitch he uses in games.     Despite some issues with his delivery and arm action, Champlain is a decent strike thrower, but he has a way to go to develop from thrower to pitcher. Signability could be a concern, with a spot at Southern California waiting should he go the college route."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 55 | Slider: 50 | Changeup: 50 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45  Sands' older brother, Carson, was a 2014 fourth-round pick of the Cubs out of high school. Cole opted to head to Florida State rather than sign in 2015 as a 22nd-round pick of the Astros. He's been a three-year member of the Seminoles' rotation and stepped into the Friday night role when Tyler Holton went down with an injury, though he missed some time with biceps tendinitis.    Assuming health, and Sands was back on the mound in May, the right-hander has a solid three-pitch mix coming from a high three-quarter delivery and easy arm action. He'll throw his fastball in the 92-95 mph range with good sink. His 80-83 mph slider is inconsistent, but it has sharp break and he can land it for strikes when it's on. His changeup should be a third average offering, a solid offspeed pitch with good sink to it as well.    Sands doesn't miss a ton of bats, but goes right after hitters. He did pitch well on the Cape in brief performances for two summers, which certainly won't hurt his chances of getting drafted in the top five rounds."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Slider: 55 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45  Tyler Jay set an Illinois record with 14 saves in 2015, when the Twins made him the No. 6 overall choice in the Draft. This spring, Gerber matched Jay by the end of the regular season and also climbed to within two of his Illini career mark of 24 saves. He won't go as high in the Draft, but he should be one of the first college relievers selected and fit in the first four or five rounds.  A pure reliever who has never started a game in three years of college or during summer ball, Gerber attacks hitters with two pitches. He has sat at 92-96 mph with his fastball throughout the spring, even when working on consecutive days. His sharp 82-85 mph slider can be a plus pitch at times and is especially tough on right-handers.  Gerber has a lot of flying parts in his funky delivery, which provides deception but also hampers his command at times. How well he can locate his pitches ultimately will determine if he reaches his ceiling as a set-up man. His strong 6-foot-4 frame and resilient arm make him a durable bullpen option and he should be one of the first 2018 Draftees to reach the big leagues."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 50 | Curveball: 50 | Changeup: 55 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45  Over the years, Cal State Fullerton has been a veritable factory producing right-handers who really know how to pitch and compete without premium stuff. In 2015, Tom Eshelman went in the second round to the Astros. Two years later, the Phillies took Connor Seabold in the third round. This year, it's Colton Eastman's turn and he's hoping to join his predecessors in the top three rounds.     The 6-foot-3 right-hander has been a solid college performer, with a highlight being throwing Fullerton's fifth no-hittter in history in late March. As a freshman, he was touching 94 mph with his fastball, but hasn't gotten back there since, typically sitting in the 89-92 mph range. Early this season, Eastman used a plus changeup with tremendous success and showed a below-average breaking ball. Over the course of the spring, his curve has bounced back and flashes above-average, but his changeup has regressed. He's a strike-thrower, but not quite with the precision Eshelman or Seabold showed during their days anchoring the Titans rotation.     Eastman missed a good chunk of his sophomore season with elbow inflammation and has not pitched over the summer in either of the past two years. He's shown no ill effects this year, though, and a team that believes he could have two above-average secondary offerings to go along with his feel for pitching could snag him early as a back-end starter type who could move quickly."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Slider: 60 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45  Hess' electric arm could have made him a top-five-rounds pick out of a Virginia high school in 2016, but his steadfast commitment to Louisiana State dropped him all the way to the Yankees in the 35th round. He opened his freshman season as a midweek starter before becoming a dominating closer in April and playing a key role in the Tigers' runner-up finish at the College World Series. He moved into the weekend rotation this spring to fill a need, and though most scouts still envision him as a reliever, he's talented enough to go in the first three rounds as a Draft-eligible sophomore.  As a starter, Hess usually works with a 91-95 mph fastball and a solid slider. When he came out of the bullpen last year, he repeatedly ran his heater into upper 90s and backed it up with a wipeout slider. He uses his low-three-quarters arm slot and 6-foot-6 frame to create angle and life that make both pitches difficult to contend with.   Hess has yet to show much aptitude for a changeup, but also hasn't really needed one yet. He has toned down his delivery some but still throws with effort, and his arm action and fringy control may have him ticketed for the bullpen in pro ball. If a pro team makes him a reliever, he could be one of the first players in the 2018 Draft to reach the big leagues."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 55 | Power: 40 | Run: 45 | Arm: 40 | Field: 45 | Overall: 45  A three-year starter at Maryland, Dunn has stood out in the wood bat Cape Cod League, being named an All-Star for two years in a row. Some of that offensive performance carried over to his junior season, where he hit for average and more power than he had previously in his career.    A left-handed hitter, Dunn has an advanced approach at the plate with very good plate discipline that allowed him to walk more than he has struck out over the course of his college career. The infielder reached double-digits in home runs as a junior, nearly doubling his total over his first two years combined, though his power at the next level is more likely to be of the extra-base, not over-the-fence, variety. With a below-average arm and fringy speed, Dunn is limited to second base.    The Terrapins had a middle infielder taken in the fourth round of the 2017 Draft in Kevin Smith, now with the Blue Jays, though he's a shortstop. Dunn may not go quite as early, but his success on the Cape, as well as his junior year, could get him off the board not long after."

mlbp_blurb: "Scouting grades: Fastball: 55 | Curveball: 50 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45    The Yankees were the favorites to land Castillo at the outset of the 2015-16 international period before an issue with the Venezuelan right-hander's physical caused the deal to fall through. He instead signed with the Blue Jays in September, and did so for just $10,000. Castillo made both his pro debut and U.S. debut the next year and then in 2017 advanced to Rookie-level Bluefield, where, at age 18, he won six of his 10 starts and posted strikeout and walk rates of 26.0 and 3.5 percent, respectively.    Castillo is already physically mature for his age, with a stocky frame that leaves little room for projection. His feel for pitching is similarly advanced, as Castillo operates at 89-92 mph with a fastball that has run and late sinking action that nets him both whiffs and ground balls. Castillo can spin a solid breaking ball but does so inconsistently, while a changeup gives him a distinct third pitch.    Castillo's strike-throwing ability is one of his strengths, but he needs to improve his fastball command so as to better set up his secondary pitches, with the goal of getting hitters to expand the zone."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 55 | Slider: 45 | Changeup: 50 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45  When Woodford was coming out of Plant High School in Tampa as a teammate of Astros prospect Kyle Tucker, he was a projectable prep right-hander with a solid feel for pitching. That pitchability remains his calling card, and though his stuff hasn't ticked up the way some anticipated, he's still had success, finishing sixth in the system in ERA in 2017.  Velocity-wise, Woodford's fastball is about average, with a four-seamer that tops out at around 94 mph, but his ability to sink his two-seamer and his command of the pitch make it play up. His changeup is solid average and his slider, while inconsistent, might get to Major League average as well. But more than anything, Woodford is a strike-throwing groundball pitcher, one who is efficient with his pitches and able to log innings when he's at his best. He may never be a big swing-and-miss guy, but there is the chance that there is a bit more in the tank stuff wise given that he'll be just 21 for all of the 2018 season.  The right-hander gets high marks for his work ethic and for understanding who he is as a pitcher. He is capable of using all of his pitches well, something he'll have to do to continue having this kind of success at the upper levels of the system."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 40 | Run: 50 | Arm: 55 | Field: 55 | Overall: 45  The last time Florida State had a shortstop who garnered early-round consideration was in 2004, when Stephen Drew was in the conversation for the No. 1 overall pick and ended up going No. 15 overall to Arizona. Walls didn't rate that highly ahead of the 2017 Draft, but his track record of success and the fact that college shortstop performers always do well in the Draft earned him a third-round selection by Tampa Bay. After making his pro debut with Class A Short Season Hudson Valley, Walls began his first full season in the Class A Midwest League with Bowling Green.  While Walls didn't hit for average in his junior year, he did as a sophomore, capping that year with a solid performance for Team USA. His best offensive skill is his plate discipline, as Walls compiled more walks (178) than strikeouts (145) during his 196-game Seminoles career. He's a switch-hitter who grinds out at-bats, with a line-drive approach and some extra-base ability, albeit with little over-the-fence power.  He's a scrappy defender with an arm that's a tick above-average. He has the tools to stay at shortstop but could be better suited for second base. Walls might profile best eventually as a super-utility type, but he has a chance to succeed as an everyday player up the middle."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Curveball: 50 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45  When the Pirates took Hinsz in the 11th round of the 2014 Draft and went well above the $100,000 threshold to sign him, they knew it would take a while for the Montana native to figure things out. The fact he had moved to the Class A Advanced Florida State League in 2017 really put him ahead of that curve, though he struggled there, with his season ending a bit early due to a scapula stress fracture. His future became even more clouded when open heart surgery to repair a faulty valve ended his season, though the Pirates are optimistic he'll be ready to go in 2019.    It's unclear how long he had been dealing with the shoulder injury, which could have impacted his overall performance in Bradenton in 2017. He's still a bit of a project, but there are the makings of a three-pitch mix in an excellent pitching frame. He's a physical power pitcher who sits close to the mid-90s with his fastball. When he's right, he throws with sink to get ground-ball outs. He's continuing to develop his secondary stuff, with a good feel to spin a power curveball and a changeup that is a work in progress. He throws strikes, but gets too much of the zone at times, leading to elevated hit rates.    Once Hinsz returns to full health, he can get back to shortening the learning curve on his long-term projection. The pieces are still there for him eventually to develop into a mid-rotation starter."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 50 | Curveball: 50 | Changeup: 50 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45  Pitchability lefties from the college ranks are not exactly uncommon, but usually they get drafted because of strong performances. Naughton struggled, numbers-wise, for much of his career at Virginia Tech, with a career 6.13 ERA, but the Reds liked his stuff and delivery enough to take a flier in the ninth round of the 2017 Draft, and he's had solid results as a pro thus far.    Naughton's stuff is largely average across the board, though movement and deception in his delivery allow it to play up. That's especially true of his fastball, a 90-94 mph heater with good tailing action that gets on hitters more quickly than expected because of his delivery. His changeup, thrown 82-85 mph, has similar life to it, and might be his best secondary offering. He also throws a solid curveball, a down-breaker thrown in the 75-78 mph range.    The Reds love the way Naughton has attacked hitters early in counts, and he generally throws strikes. His ceiling is that of a back-end starter, though there's a chance he could end up in a bullpen eventually."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 50 | Curveball: 55 | Changeup: 50 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45  After signing for $50,000 out of the Dominican Republic in 2012, Garabito spent his first three seasons in Rookie ball. When he finally made the jump to low Class A in 2016, he went 2-11 with a 4.80 ERA, though the Royals thought he showed more promise than that record indicated. He looked much better when he returned to Lexington last year, slicing his ERA to 2.81, though he missed more than two months with shoulder tendinitis.   Garabito's upper-70s curveball has depth and often serves as his most effective option. He showed more trust in his fading changeup during 2017, when he held left-handers to a .584 OPS. His fastball parks at 90-93 mph, peaks at 95 and is relatively straight, which makes it both easier to command and to hit.  While Garabito lacks a plus pitch, he can throw strikes with all three of them despite a relatively long arm action. He's not very physical or projectable, so his ceiling is limited to a back-of-the-rotation starter. He does have some of the best pitchability and one of the better floors among Kansas City farmhands."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Slider: 55 | Splitter: 50 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45  An Auburn transfer from the junior college ranks, Klobosits pitched to underwhelming results for two seasons out of the Tigers' bullpen ahead of his selection by the Nationals in the 36th round of the 2017 Draft. But after a stellar pro debut in which Klobosits posted a 1.47 ERA with 10.0 strikeouts-per-nine across three levels including Class A Hagerstown, it's clear that the Nationals drafted a better player than even they had expected.   An imposing presence on the mound at 6-foot-7, Klobosits has the ability to dominate hitters with his blend of size, stuff and deception.
