He uses his height to create good angle on a plus fastball that sits in the mid-90s with late life. His slider is his go-to secondary offering, flashing above average, and he also demonstrates feel for throwing a splitter. Klobosits had no problems throwing strikes in his pro debut after pitching with below-average control as an amateur.   Klobosits' strike-throwing ability will be tested at higher levels, as will the consistency and quality of his stuff. But if his pro debut is a sign of what's to come, Klobosits could make a quick rise through the Minors en route to a late-inning role in Washington's bullpen."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Curveball: 55 | Slider: 55 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45  Part of a Blue Jays 2011 international class that provided plenty of trade fodder, Tinoco signed for $400,000 out of Venezuela and went to the Rockies in the Troy Tulowitzki deal four years later. He starred in low Class A immediately after switching organizations, but his delivery fell apart the following spring and he went 3-11 with a 6.86 ERA at two Class A stops in 2016. His fortunes suddenly reversed again last year, where he embraced changes to his mechanics, finished strong and earned a spot on Colorado's 40-man roster.  Tinoco's best pitch is his fastball that usually ranges from 93-95 mph and tops out at 97 with sink. He has a pair of power breaking balls, with his curveball and slider both plus pitches at their best but also inconsistent. He's making strides with his changeup though it still ranks as his fourth-best pitch.  Tinoco's downturn came when his delivery became too violent, causing him to fall off toward first base and lose any semblance of command. He has cleaned up his mechanics, taking a more direct route to the plate and doing a better job of locating his pitches. Though the Rockies will continue to develop him as a starter, he could have success as a late-inning reliever with a power arsenal."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 35 | Run: 55 | Arm: 55 | Field: 60 | Overall: 45  McCoy spent his first two collegiate seasons at Illinois Central Community College before transferring to Iowa as a junior and going unselected in the Draft. He excelled that summer while playing in the Northwoods collegiate summer league, earning MVP honors and breaking the league record for hits (111), and then built on that performance as a senior by slashing .328/.394/.474. Impressed with McCoy's progress and all-around skills, the Orioles made him their sixth-round pick in 2017, and he rewarded them with a strong pro debut as Class A Aberdeen's everyday shortstop.   McCoy can do a little bit of everything on the field, most notably hit for average while offering plus defense at shortstop. He's fundamentally sound there, showing good range, soft hands and a strong arm, as well as consistency that has long impressed evaluators. At the plate, McCoy offers little in the way of power but has a disciplined approach and good feel for hitting to all fields.  The Orioles liken McCoy's abilities to those of former big league shortstops Walt Weiss and Mike Bordick, players who stood out for their sum of all parts rather than specific tools. With further development, McCoy could reach the Major Leagues in a utility infielder role."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Curveball: 50 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45  Bahr barely saw the mound his first three years at Central Florida, redshirting as a walk-on in 2014, walking more batters (three) than he retired (two) in 2015 and getting cut the following year. A new coaching staff was impressed by his performance during summer and brought him back to the Knights, for whom he ranked second in NCAA Division I in strikeout rate (14.5 per nine innings) as a redshirt junior in 2017. He had a decent pro debut after signing for a below-slot $250,000 in the fifth round, then opened this year by allowing a total of seven earned runs in his first seven starts in low Class A.  Bahr sits in the low 90s with his fastball as a starter and has reached 96 mph in shorter stints. He has a lanky 6-foot-5 frame with room to add strength and thus more velocity, though at age 23 it's unclear how much projection he has remaining. He doesn't need to throw harder, however, because his heater plays up because of his extension and high spin rate.  While he comes with low mileage on his arm, Bahr also lacks experience and needs to refine his secondary pitches. He has made encouraging progress with his curveball in the early going in 2018, giving hope that it can become a solid breaking ball, but his changeup is still in its nascent stages. He has no problems providing strikes and does a good job of keeping the ball down in the zone."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Slider: 55 | Curveball: 50 | Changeup: 50 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45  Thompson used a sinker/slider approach to great effect in 2017, leading NCAA Division I in victories while going 14-1 with a 1.96 ERA for a 56-6 Oregon State club that finished third at the College World Series. After the Red Sox signed the redshirt junior for a slightly below-slot $350,000 as a fourth-rounder, he told them that though the Beavers had him focus on two pitches, he also threw a curveball and changeup. He worked only 11 1/3 innings in his pro debut, but that was enough to show the makings of a possible mid-rotation starter.  Thompson's 92-94 mph sinker and 82-85 mph slider with bite both can be plus pitches. He also took to using a four-seam fastball more often, peaking at 98 mph with armside run. He flashed a plus changeup during his debut and mixed in a curve that should be at least average.  With a deeper repertoire, Thompson has a better chance of remaining a starter. In college, several scouts projected him as a reliever because he lacks a smooth delivery and didn't have much success in his first three seasons at Oregon State (missing most of 2015 with a back injury). He did a better job of throwing strikes after simplifying his mechanics last year and Boston is eager to see how his stuff plays over his first full pro season."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Slider: 60 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45    Burrows took over the closer role at the University of Alabama as a freshman and never let go of it. After three years, he held the career saves record for the school, which resulted in him being taken by the Mariners in the fourth round of the 2016 Draft. After a summer of saving some more games in the Short Season Northwest League, Burrows was sent to the Braves along with Luiz Gohara in return for Mallex Smith and Shae Simmons.    The lefty reliever didn't rack up saves in his first full season, but he did pitch very effectively in the South Atlantic League, striking out 12.4 per nine innings and keeping hitters to a .198 batting average against. He does it with a solid two-pitch mix, really all he needs to succeed in short relief. His fastball sits in the low-90s and touches 95 mph, but it plays up because it has plus movement and comes from a low three-quarters arm slot. His sweeping slider gets swings and misses from hitters on both sides of the plate. He has less than pinpoint command, but throws enough strikes to be effective.    After Burrows spent the entire season at one level, look for him to start moving a little more quickly with his two plus pitches. While he's unlikely to close again, he does have the chance to be an effective lefty setup or middle man in the future."

"Scouting Grades: Fastball: 50 | Slider: 50 | Changeup: 50 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45  Waddell looked like the prototypical pitchability college lefty after two strong seasons at the University of Virginia, including a starring role in the College World Series. He backed that up by pitching most of his first full season of pro ball in Double-A after the Pirates took him in the fifth round of the 2015 Draft. A combination of so-so performance and injuries have caused him to stall a bit.  Waddell does have a good feel to pitch and knows how to move the ball around the zone. But he tends to nibble too much and work off the plate, leading to a much higher walk rate than is desirable from a finesse lefty. He has average stuff across the board, with a fastball that sits around 90-91 mph and works best when he keeps it down in the zone to get groundball outs, an average slider and a changeup that usually has good fade to it. The Pirates have preached to him about being more efficient and force contact earlier in counts because he is not overly physical and long innings will make it harder for him to hold up as a starter. He did have two disabled list stints with a forearm strain in 2017.  Waddell made up for some lost innings and pitched largely in relief in the Arizona Fall League, throwing better during that limited stretch. He doesn't really have the stuff to be pitch out of the pen, so he'll have to make strides in attacking hitters to reach his potential as a back-end starter."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 40 | Run: 50 | Arm: 45 | Field: 55 | Overall: 45    Walton turned down the Mets as a 36th-rounder in 2012 to honor his commitment to Oklahoma State, where he became a three-time All-Big 12 First Team selection. Though he was drafted once again in 2015, this time by the Brewers in the 23rd round, Walton opted to return for his senior year and had his best offensive season, culminating with his selection in the fifth round by Seattle in June. Making the jump to Class A Advanced Modesto for his first full season, Walton impressed with his play on both sides of the ball in the California League, but also spent nearly two months on the disabled list with a wrist injury.    What Walton lacks in tools he makes up for with excellent instincts and all-around consistency. He's a capable switch-hitter but does most of his damage from the left side, showing good bat speed and feel to hit as well as surprising power given his size. His average speed plays up on the basepaths due to his aforementioned instincts, and he's adept at reading pitchers and picking his spots to run.    Defensively, Walton saw more time at shortstop than second base in 2017, though most scouts view him as a second baseman long term because he has below-average arm strength. The Mariners will continue to deploy Walton at both positions moving forward, as they believe he has the necessary tools to become a utility infielder at the highest level."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Curveball: 50 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45  It hasn't exactly been a direct path for Anderson since he joined the Phillies almost as an afterthought, a 21st-round pick out of his Reno high school in 2012. He moved slowly, not making it to full-season ball until 2014 and then missing the 2015 season following Tommy John surgery. After he came back throwing well in 2016, he was added to the 40-man roster despite not having pitched above A ball. Anderson rewarded their faith with a strong 2017 season that saw him make his big league debut in relief.    The further he puts the elbow surgery in the rearview mirror, the better Anderson's outlook is. With another healthy offseason behind him, he's ready to continue refining his stuff as a future starter. His fastball-curveball combination is extremely good, with a heater that has really strong finish, especially up in the zone. His 11-to-5 curve is thrown with depth and can miss bats and he showed good improvement with his changeup in 2017.    Anderson is still developing, as he continues to work on his consistency in the strike zone. He got a small taste of the big leagues last season; he should be ready to contribute on a larger scale as a starter soon."

"Scouting Grades: Fastball: 50 | Curve: 55 | Slider: 50 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45  Acquired by Atlanta from the Mets at the Trade Deadline in July 2015, Whalen excelled at the Double-A and Triple-A levels in '16 to earn a big league callup in August at age 22. However, shoulder fatigue combined with a team-imposed inning cap limited the right-hander to just five starts with the Braves, who then sent him and Max Povse to the Mariners for '14 first-rounder Alex Jackson in late November. He returned to the big leagues in 2017 with Seattle, but also missed considerable time with leg and knee injuries early in the season before taking the rest of the year off in July to address mental health issues.  Whalen pitches with an average fastball, sitting at 90-93 mph, but it plays up thanks to heavy sinking action that yields a high number of ground balls. His curveball is his lone above-average pitch, and he also mixes in a slider and a usable changeup. The right-hander is around the strike zone with all of his pitches and knows how to keep hitters off balance and guessing by effectively changing speeds.  With an advanced feel for four pitches as well as a bulldog mentality on the mound, Whalen shows the makings of becoming a backend starter at maturity. Perhaps more importantly, Whalen, after receiving treatment for depression and anxiety that affected him for much of 2017, has returned to the game as an advocate for mental health and hopes to change its stigma within the sport."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 50 | Curveball: 50 | Changeup: 50 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45  After taking Dansby Swanson with the No. 1 overall pick in the 2015 Draft, the D-backs went college-pitching heavy, selecting one with each of their next five picks. Young was the first in that group taken, in the second round out of TCU. The lefty made a fairly successful jump to Double-A in his second full season, finishing seventh in the system in ERA.    Young relies on a three-pitch mix and his ability to throw them for strikes, rather than any one true out pitch. His fastball is average, thrown around 91-92 mph. His breaking ball, which was more of a slider when he entered pro ball, has morphed into more of a curveball and grades out as Major League average. The lefty has worked on his changeup a lot and it's caught up to his breaking ball, giving him a third average offering. There isn't a whole lot of margin for error for Young, so his ability to command all three is important. He did a much better job of doing that down in the zone in the second half of his 2017 season.    Young did pitch out of the bullpen at times with TCU and he looked good doing so during his brief pro debut in 2015. The D-backs plan to continue to let him start and see if he can keep developing into a back-end starter, knowing the stuff would tick up a bit in shorter relief stints."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 55 | Slider: 50 | Curveball: 50 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45  A fifth-round Draft pick in 2014 out of Tennessee Tech, Hess made steady progress early in his career while reaching Double-A in his first full season. Though he struggled the following year over a full season in the Eastern League, Hess rebounded in his return to the level in 2017, posting a 3.85 ERA and logging a career-high 154 1/3 innings, and the Orioles added him to their 40-man roster after the season.   Hess attacks the zone from an over-the-top slot that helps him achieve downhill plane with a fastball that ranges from 89-95 mph and usually sits around 93. Both his slider and curveball are average offerings, with the former currently grading ahead of the latter, though he can get caught between them at times. He also has a serviceable changeup that plays against left-handed hitters and demonstrates average control of his four-pitch mix.   Questions remain about whether Hess, with his high-effort delivery and lack of an out pitch, can remain a starter. It's long been thought that his stuff would play up in short bursts out of the bullpen, where his fastball-breaking ball pairing could make him a force against right-handed hitters."

"Scouting grades:  Fastball: 70 | Slider: 45 | Changeup: 40 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45  Rhame's college career in Oklahoma didn't start so well as a freshman, but he got straightened out with a move to Grayson Junior College. A starter there, he was selected by the Dodgers in the sixth round of the 2013 Draft and his arm strength was immediately moved to the bullpen. He pitched all year in Triple-A in 2017, then was dealt to the Mets in last August's Curtis Granderson deal and he made his big league debut for New York in September.  Rhame has, and always will be, primarily about his fastball. It will sit 95-96 mph with plus riding life and he can reach back for upper-90s heat on occasion. That's his go-to pitch, but while his secondary stuff is fringy, at best, he does have two other offerings he uses. His slider will show glimpses of being a sharp breaking ball, but it's been inconsistent. His changeup is below-average, but it has shown improvement. He's generally been around the strike zone throughout his career.  It's hard to define a future Major League role for a one-pitch reliever, even if it's a really good pitch. Continued development of his secondary stuff to help keep big league hitters from sitting on his fastball, certainly would help."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 55 | Cutter: 55 | Slider: 50 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45  Naile returned from Tommy John surgery to pace Conference USA in strikeouts and innings in 2015, the same year that the A's took the Alabama-Birmingham hurler in the 20th round. Though he reached Triple-A while pitching at four levels last year in his first full professional season, Naile's shining moment came the next year in the Texas League finals, when he tossed six scoreless frames to lead Double-A Midland to its third straight title. Naile helped the RockHounds secure yet another title in 2017, though he also spent two months on the disabled list with an oblique injury.  Naile relies heavily on his sinker, a low-90s offering that he consistently commands down in the zone and that has netted him twice as many ground-ball outs than air outs in his career. He can manipulate the pitch, too, at times imparting cutting action in order to keep hitters true. His slider is an average offering, thrown in the upper 70s, and he'll also mix in a firm changeup that grades as his least advanced offering. Naile's arsenal plays up thanks to his strike-throwing ability and bulldog mentality on the mound.  Outside of the injury that sidelined him in 2017, Naile has proven plenty durable during his professional career. He also receives high praise for his defense -- he was a Minor League Gold Glove winner in 2016 -- and feel for controlling the running game. Naile will continue to be developed as a starter, but he also could reach the Majors quickly in a bullpen role, possibly as a long reliever, thanks to his excellent ground-ball tendencies."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 40 | Run: 55 | Arm: 50 | Field: 50 | Overall: 45  Ferguson and Dodgers corner infielder Matt Beaty are battling to become the first Belmont position player to reach the big leagues after teaming up for four years in college. Both parlayed huge senior seasons into pro contracts in 2015, with Ferguson signing with the Astros for $1,000 as a 19th-rounder after hitting .395/.486/.682. He breezed through the Minors before struggling when he got to Triple-A last August.  Houston executives rave about Ferguson's baseball IQ, which helps him play above his tools -- not that there are any glaring deficiencies with his tools. He makes consistent hard contact with a sound right-handed swing and a patient gameplan. Though he has a compact build, he has average power and could produce 12-15 homers per year if he tried to drive the ball more often.  Ferguson has solid speed and uses it well on the bases and in center field. After getting relegated to the corners in his first two seasons while playing along higher-profile prospects, he showed that he could handle center in 2017. His average arm adds to his versatility, allowing him to man all three outfield spots."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Slider: 50 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45    Kline excelled both as a closer and starter at the University of Virginia before the Orioles made him their second-round pick in 2012. He got off to a strong start in '15 in his first Double-A campaign, only to suffer an early-season elbow injury for which he received a platelet-rich plasma injection. Kline's elbow continued to bother him that fall during instructional league play -- leading to Tommy John surgery that would cost him all of '16 -- while a pair of arthroscopic surgeries to address lodged tissue in the joint line in his right elbow kept him off the mound again in '17. Finally healthy to begin '18, Kline ended a 59-month absence on the mound when he logged a scoreless performance out of Class A Advanced Frederick's bullpen on Minor League Opening Day.     Kline, when healthy, boasts an impressive fastball-slider pairing. He's shown the same velocity in 2018 as he did pre-injury, sitting in the low- to mid-90s and bumping 97-98 mph while using his 6-foot-3 frame to create a downhill angle to the plate. Kline's slider is inconsistent at times but highly effective against right-handed hitters, giving him a two-pitch combo that's ideal for late-inning bullpen work. He'll also mix in the occasional changeup. Kline has long been a strike-thrower, but will need to refine his command after his extended layoff.    A starting pitcher prior to his injuries, Kline was shifted to the bullpen ahead of his return and has quickly impressed in the new role, showing a combination of size, stuff and feel that has him back on track toward reaching the Major Leagues."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 65 | Curveball: 45 | Cutter: 55 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45  The A's viewed Trivino as a starter when they selected him in the 11th round of the 2013 Draft out of Division II Slippery Rock University. But he pitched to mixed results in the role during his first two seasons, and two years later the A's moved him to the bullpen full-time. Trivino has subsequently blossomed as a reliever, and done so while making a steady climb through the A's system. He pitched to a 3.30 ERA and averaged nearly a strikeout per inning in 2017 while making a career-high 48 appearances across the Double- and Triple-A levels. After the season, the A's added Trivino to their 40-man roster.   Listed at 6-foot-5, 225 pounds, Trivino stands out on the mound for his physicality. The big right-hander's stuff is plenty good, too, as he'll run his fastball into the upper 90s while also showing good feel for a low-90s cutter and a quality breaking ball in the low 80s. Meanwhile, after making some key adjustments to his delivery, Trivino made strides as a strike-thrower in 2017 and walked one fewer batter per nine innings than he did the previous year.   Trivino's combination of a high-effort delivery and downhill angle to the plate makes his stuff extremely difficult to lift, so much so that opposing hitters have tagged him for just two home runs in 178 1/3 career relief innings, none of which came in 2017. His breaking ball and control both require further improvement, but the raw ingredients are there for Trivino to serve as a late-inning weapon for the A's in the near future."

mlbd_blurb: "Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 35 | Run: 60 | Arm: 50 | Field: 55 | Overall: 45  Holland impressed on the showcase circuit last summer and has established himself as the best up-the-middle position prospect among Texas high schoolers this spring. He could fit in the first four or five rounds, though whether that will be early enough to sign him away from a commitment to Texas remains to be seen.  As the son of noted Houston-area hitting coach Sid Holland, it's no surprise that Holland has a quality right-handed swing. He doesn't try to do too much at the plate, satisfying himself with hitting line drives from gap to gap. He has some bat speed but isn't very physical, so most of his power will come in the form of doubles.  Holland's best tool is his plus speed, though he's still learning how to get the most out of it as a basestealer and defender. He's a solid center fielder with average arm strength. While he can play all three outfield positions, he doesn't have the pop to profile on the corners."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Curveball: 50 | Changeup: 40 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45  In a relatively down year in Southern California, Cole Winn has separated himself as clearly the best high school arm in the region. While there's quite a bit separating the pair, Champlain is generally thought to be No. 2 and is all about projection and future potential.    Champlain does have a big fastball now and a 6-foot-4 frame that could add strength, making it easy to dream on move velocity to come. His fastball sits in the low 90s, has touched higher at times, with some good life down in the zone. He has good feel for his breaking ball, a curve that should be a least an average secondary pitch for him. His changeup is very much a work in progress and it's not a pitch he uses in games.     Despite some issues with his delivery and arm action, Champlain is a decent strike thrower, but he has a way to go to develop from thrower to pitcher. Signability could be a concern, with a spot at Southern California waiting should he go the college route."

mi_blurb: "Age 23, from Venezuela, hit .341/.376/.466 with 34 doubles, 11 triples, three homers, 31 steals, 30 walks, 88 strikeouts in 519 at-bats in High-A; hit almost as well on the road (.331/.377/.434) as at home (.350/.375/.495) so this isnt just a mere Lancaster illusion, we do need to see him in Double-A of course but he caught the eye of Cal League observers with speed, gap power, and throwing arm; he caught the attention of other teams, too, so the Rockies protected him on the 40-man roster as otherwise someone would probably have taken him in the Rule 5 draft; ETA 2020."
mlbp_blurb: "Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 25 | Run: 60 | Arm: 70 | Field: 60 | Overall: 45  Signed out of Venezuela in 2010, Daza spent three mostly undistinguished seasons in the Rookie-level Dominican Summer League. He ranked second in the Rookie-level Pioneer League with a .370 average in his 2014 U.S. debut and has hit .303 every year since, winning the high Class A California League batting title at .341 last year. He performed nearly as well on the road (.331/.377/.434) as he did at hitter-friendly Lancaster (.350/.375/.495), then hit .318 in the Arizona Fall League.  Daza is a gifted hitter with a knack for serving line drives to the opposite field. His approach yields very little home run power, however, and the ease with which he makes contact cuts into his walk totals. He has gotten faster as he has firmed up his body and now has plus speed and some basestealing acumen.  While there's some question whether Daza can make enough offensive impact to warrant playing every day at the big league level, his speed and defensive ability give him value as a fourth outfielder. He's the best center-field defender in the system, with his quick first step and fine instincts allowing him to cover plenty of ground. He also has the strongest outfield arm among Rockies farmhands, enabling him to play all three spots."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 45 | Run: 35 | Arm: 60 | Field: 45 | Overall: 45    The Cardinals signed Montero for $300,000 in August 2014, the largest bonus for a hitter the organization gave out in that signing period, because they liked his offensive upside. After two summers playing in the Dominican Summer League, he was one of the better performers in the Gulf Coast League during his United States debut in 2017.    Montero's potential lies in what he can do with the bat from the right side of the plate. He has a compact stroke that allows him to make consistent contact and translates to outstanding raw power he is still learning to tap into on a regular basis. He has a solid approach at the plate and isn't afraid to draw walks. His best defensive tool is his arm and the Cardinals think he has the hands and actions to stay at third long-term.     Others think he might outgrow the hot corner and a lack of speed does limit his range to an extent. The good news is that if his bat continues to progress, he might profile well at either infield corner when all is said and done."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 35 | Run: 50 | Arm: 50 | Field: 50 | Overall: 45  De la Guerra was eligible for four straight Drafts from 2011-14 but went unselected as a California high school senior, JC of the Canyons (Calif.) freshman and sophomore and a Grand Canyon junior. He won the Western Athletic Conference batting title with a .373 average in 2014 and encored with a 24-game hitting streak in 2015, when the Red Sox made him a $5,000 senior sign in the 17th round. After not hitting much in his first two pro seasons and fracturing his lower leg in 2016, he batted .283/.361/.437 while advancing to Double-A last season.  De la Guerra's instincts and inner drive stand out more than any of his tools, none of which grade better than average. However, he has a knack for making consistent line-drive contract and draws enough walks to post solid on-base percentages. He won't drive many balls over the fence but will lace his share of doubles to the gaps.  A second baseman for much of his first two years as a pro, de la Guerra spent most of 2017 at shortstop. He enhanced his utility profile by proving capable at shortstop and also saw action at third base in the Arizona Fall League. He's a steady if unspectacular defender with reliable hands and average arm strength."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 40 | Run: 35 | Arm: 55 | Field: 55 | Overall: 45  Selected in the 10th round in 2013 following his senior year at Fresno State, Wynns made progress on both sides of the ball during his first two seasons before breaking out in earnest in '17 with a career-best performance across three levels including Triple-A. That across-the-board improvement prompted the Orioles to add Wynns to their 40-man roster after the season.   Wynns is a strong defender behind the plate with above-average arm strength and advanced catch-and-throw skills that enabled him to throw out more than 38 percent of attempted basestealers in 2017. He also made strides with his blocking, and club officials speak highly of his feel for calling a game. No slouch with the bat, Wynns slashed .281/.377/.419 while establishing career highs in home runs (10), doubles (19) and walks (54).   Wynns' breakout performance has thrust him into the Major League spotlight, portending a possible backup role for the 27-year-old catcher."

mlbd_blurb: "Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 50 | Run: 35 | Arm: 45 | Field: 45 | Overall: 45  Raleigh comes from a baseball family, with a father and uncle who both played at Western Carolina. His dad went on to coach at his alma mater and at Tennessee, while his uncle spent 10 years in the Minor Leagues. The younger Raleigh jumped on the map as a freshman at Florida State, scuffled as a sophomore, but has bounced back with a strong junior season, at least with the bat.    The switch-hitting backstop has swung the bat well, especially in the second half of his junior season, using an advanced approach at the plate to hit for average and power while drawing a ton of walks. It's more power over hit, with some concern over him hitting enough at the next level to tap consistently into that raw pop. Raleigh's defensive game, however, has not taken the same step forward this year. Not overly athletic, he hasn't been very agile behind the plate and his blocking and receiving have been inconsistent, as has been his arm.    College catching is always hard to find, and Raleigh has done it for three years at Florida State. Teams will be buying the bat here, with the hope that he'll defend just well enough to stick there as an offensive-minded catcher."

mlbp_blurb: "Scouting grades: Fastball: 55 | Curveball: 50 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45    Scouts spent a lot of time in Overland Park, Kan., leading up to the 2016 Draft. Yes, many were there to see Riley Pint, who ended going No. 4 overall to the Rockies in that June's Draft. But they surely checked in on another 6-foot-4 projectable right-hander in Duensing, who ended going in the sixth round and got an above-pick value deal to walk away from his Kansas State commitment.    While Duensing threw well in his brief pro debut that summer, he had some serious ups and downs in 2017. Most of his issues stemmed from issues with his delivery, as he struggled to be consistent with it and his arm slot all summer. As a result, his stuff fluctuated greatly, with a low-90s fastball that dipped below that at times and a breaking ball that would flash solid average occasionally, but would be a lot less serviceable than that a lot of the time.    Duensing's delivery problems also led to control trouble, but the good news is he made positive strides during instructs on smoothing out some of the kinks. He's athletic and has plus makeup, so there is cautious optimism he can carry those lessons over to competition in 2018."

mlbd_blurb: "Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Slider: 45 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45  A New Jersey high school right-hander hasn't been taken in the top five round since Joe Gatto was a second-rounder back in 2014, and Gatto was the first one since 2008 (Jason Knapp, second round). Ras, thanks to his arm strength and athleticism, has the chance to join a very select group.    Ras is a two-way stand out at Middletown High School who has separated himself as a pitching prospect. He's projectable at 6-foot-4 and has been up to 93 mph with his fastball, with more in the tank as he fills out that frame. He's at his best when he stays on top and throws downhill, creating good life on that heater. His secondary stuff is behind his fastball, though his slurvy breaking ball and his changeup show glimpses of being solid offerings. Some scouts don't love his arm action and delivery, but with his athleticism, there's hope things could be corrected with instruction.    There are teams that don't shy away from pitching projects, and Ras certainly would be one. He's committed to the University of Alabama, but it's easy to dream on what he can become once he's focusing only on the mound."

mlbp_blurb: "Scouting grades: Fastball: 55 | Curveball: 55 | Changeup: 40 | Control: 40 | Overall: 45  Part of Washington's 2014-15 international class, Alastre has impressed the club with the quick progress he's made early in his career. After a rocky U.S. debut in the Rookie-level Gulf Coast League, Alastre was overmatched with an Opening Day assignment to Class A Short-Season Auburn in 2017. The right-hander fared much better back in the Rookie-level Gulf Coast League, where he showed improved feel for his promising stuff.  Young and projectable, Alastre uses his height to leverage the baseball to the plate, working in the low-90s with his fastball and pairing it with an above-average curveball that features 12-to-6, downer shape. Club officials expect Alastre to add more velocity as he grows into his lean and athletic frame.  The Nationals speak highly of Alastre's cerebral approach to pitching and expect his control and command to both improve as he gains experience and develops physically. He's poised to make gains on that front in 2018, in his age-20 season."

mi_blurb: "Age 21, signed out of Venezuela in 2013; hit .242/.304/.402 with 17 homers, 36 walks, 116 strikeouts in 523 at-bats in Double-A; scouting reports have always been ahead of his production; optimists see a polished, mechanically-sound swing with solid defensive skills; pessimists say his power is inadequate for a first baseman and that his polish as a hitter is over-rated and not supported by the numbers; optimists counter that he is very young and has time to improve and tap his power more often. I fall somewhere in the middle, having seen both good and bad in specific games from him; Id be surprised if he becomes an impact player but he could last a long time as a role bat.  ETA 2019."
mlbp_blurb: "Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 45 | Run: 45 | Arm: 45 | Field: 45 | Overall: 45  Duenez received the largest bonus in the Royals' 2012-13 international class, signing for $425,000 as a third baseman out of Venezuela. He immediately moved to first base in pro ball and hit just two homers in his first three seasons before going deep 30 times in the last two years. He finished third in the Double-A Texas League with 75 RBI and fifth with 17 homers in 2017.  Duenez made a conscious decision to add leverage to his left-handed swing during instructional league following the 2015 season. He still does a nice job of using the entire field, though he doesn't control the strike zone nearly as well as he did before he started gearing up for power. While he has reduced his groundball rate, he'll need to do so further in order to have enough pop to profile as a regular at the big league level.  Though Duenez has just fringy speed, that's more than most first basemen and his 47 steals in 59 attempts during his first three years in full-season ball attest to his instincts on the bases. He's an adequate defender at first base but needs more consistency after leading the TL with 10 errors there last year. He has enough mobility and arm strength to have seen extensive action in left field in the past."

mi_blurb: "Age 22, fourth round pick in 2017 from Vanderbilt, hit .263/.377/.349 with 38 walks, 45 strikeouts in 209 at-bats in NY-P; very polished, with excellent strike zone judgment in left-side bat; very solid glove at third base; main question is power development, should hit doubles but unclear how many homers will come at higher levels. ETA 2020."
mlbp_blurb: "Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 45 | Run: 45 | Arm: 55 | Field: 55 | Overall: 45  A baseball and hockey star at Salisbury (Conn). Prep, where his brother John coached him in both sports, Toffey turned down the Yankees as a 23rd-rounder in 2014 to attend Vanderbilt. He started from day one with the Commodores, playing on their 2015 College World Series runners-up before slumping as a Draft-eligible sophomore in 2016, when the Orioles took a flier on him in the 25th round. He rebounded in the Cape Cod League that summer and was Vandy's best hitter as a junior, when he paced the team in all three triple-slash categories (.354/.475/.602) and belted 12 homers. After signing with the A's for slot value as their fourth-round pick, Toffey turned in a solid if unspectacular professional debut at Class A Short Season Vermont.  Toffey controls the strike zone very well and shows power potential in his left-handed swing. He improved his walk and strikeout rates each year at Vandy and hit for more power than ever in 2017. While he didn't show that same power during his pro debut in the New York-Penn League, Toffey still amassed 14 extra-base hits and scored 38 runs while walking at a 15-percent clip. Though he's a fringy runner, Toffey provides quality defense and solid arm strength at third baseman.   Despite his productive junior season, some evaluators wonder if Toffey has enough bat speed to hit for the average and power demanded of third basemen at higher levels. However, even those who question his tools give him credit for his ability to process the game, his makeup and his competitiveness."

mi_blurb: "Age 23, seventh round pick in 2015 from Cal Poly, hit .300/.385/.472 between High-A and Double-A with 60 walks, 70 strikeouts, 15 homers in 436 at-bats; plus raw power in 6-3, 230 pound body but game power plays lower due to line drive swing; very good eye for the strike zone helps and more homers may come in time; lacks the athleticism and mobility to play anywhere but first base and even there hes below-average overall; I like his bat and he could put up big numbers especially in thin air, but where do you play him? ETA 2019."
mlbp_blurb: "Scouting grades: Hit: 55 | Power: 45 | Run: 30 | Arm: 40 | Field: 45 | Overall: 45  Mundell mostly DHed and had an unremarkable three-year career at Cal Poly, yet the Rockies made him the first position player they selected (seventh round) in 2015. His first full pro season was a rousing success, as he set a modern Minor League record with 59 doubles and led the low Class A South Atlantic League in hits (168), extra-base hits (74), total bases (271) and RBIs (83). He continued to hit in 2017, albeit with a lot fewer doubles (28), while advancing to Double-A.  Mundell focuses on managing the strike zone and making consistent contact. A right-handed hitter, he excels at driving balls to the opposite field and hit 13 of his 15 homers last year to the left side. He has the bat speed, strength and discipline to provide more power if he began turning on more pitches.  Originally recruited as a catcher in college, Mundell has limited quickness and range but has worked hard to become an adequate defender at first base. He does have soft hands and is improving his instincts with experience. Club officials praise his leadership skills."

mi_blurb: "Age 24, seventh round pick in 2012 from high school in San Diego, California; posted 2.28 ERA with 119/40 K/BB in 134 innings in Double-A, 118 hits; soft-tosser when drafted, which has probably hampered his reputation to this point; fastball is now in the good enough range at 90-95, which works due to his ability to locate; has a complete arsenal of secondaries with curve, slider, change; all pitches generally considered average, nothing terrific but he knows how to use them; likely a fourth starter but could max out along Collin McHugh lines; ETA late 2018; QUESTION MARK: see Chris Flexen."
mlbp_blurb: "Scouting grades:Fastball: 50 | Curveball: 55 | Slider: 45 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45  The move to Double-A is often the ultimate test for a prospect, with the general thinking being that if someone can succeed at that level, he can compete in the big leagues. If that's the case, Oswalt should be a big league starter soon after the 2012 seventh-round pick moved to the Eastern League in ERA and promptly led it in ERA and finished in the top 10 in a host of other pitching categories.  While the San Diego native took a while to get going, making it to full-season ball in his fourth season, he's moved progressively since, using a solid four-pitch mix to get outs. Oswalt will throw his fastball in the 90-95 mph range and uses his 6-foot-5 frame well, throwing downhill and getting some sink on his heater to get groundball outs. His best pitch is his above-average curve, which has good depth and 12-to-6 shape to it, and he'll mix in a slider and a changeup to keep hitters guessing. Oswalt made a nice adjustment in getting his delivery more in line -- he had been cutting himself off -- and that has led to more consistent quality strikes.  Oswalt's ceiling is somewhat limited to that of a back-end starter, but he's very close to reaching that and impacting a big league rotation. The Mets added him to the 40-man roster this offseason as a result."

mi_blurb: "Age 24, fourth round pick in 2015 from University of Miami Hurricanes; at the time was considered a strong hitter with a questionable glove; his defense has turned out to be pretty good at third base and he can stay there, but bat has been merely solid rather than excellent; hit .263/.325/.429 with 16 homers, 40 walks, 92 strikeouts in 476 at-bats in Double-A; I like him more than many other people do and he could put up big numbers in Las Vegas; ETA late 2018; QUESTION MARK: will he fully tap his raw power?"
mlbp_blurb: "Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 55 | Run: 30 | Arm: 45 | Field: 50 | Overall: 45  After two relatively nondescript and injury-riddled seasons at Miami, Thompson broke out during his junior year with 19 home runs to place him among the Division I leaders. That led to the Mets taking the third baseman in the fourth round of the 2015 Draft. He played in Double-A in his second full season, finishing in the top five in the system in both home runs and RBIs before capping things off with a strong showing in the Arizona Fall League.  Thompson showed the ability to make solid adjustments at the plate in 2017, shaking off a .184/.217/.241 April by hitting .280 with 15 home runs the rest of the way, not to mention his .328/.371/.569 line in 58 AFL at-bats. The adjustments led to more consistent hard contact and allowed him to tap into his plus raw power more frequently. While he is a well below-average runner who was very rough defensively when he entered pro ball, he has improved tremendously and now projects as a solid average defender at the hot corner.  Thompson has now reached the upper levels of the Mets system and will try to hit his way to Citi Field in 2018. How much he can continue to hit and reach his power could ultimately determine whether he can be a big league regular at third for a contending team."

mlbd_blurb: "Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Slider: 55 | Curveball: 50 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45  Missouri State has sent 11 pitchers to the big leagues since the turn of the century, and Coleman is talented enough to add to that total. An unheralded recruit out of Potosi (Mo.) High, where he broke a 45-year-old career scoring record in basketball, he earned a spot in the Bears rotation at the outset of his freshman season. He led the Missouri Valley Conference with in strikeouts (106) as a sophomore and is on course to do so again in 2018.  Coleman lacks consistency, with the quality of his pitches and even more with his command, but when he's on he can can display stuff worth of a late first-round selection. He can pitch at 92-94 mph with a fastball that has reached 98 mph and features some run and sink, and he can back it up with a sharp mid-80s slider. But there also are times when his heater and slider lose some power and flatten out.  Coleman has yet to show much feel for a changeup and also possesses a curveball that isn't as reliable as his slider. He starts slow with his delivery before speeding up his tempo, which leads to him getting out of sync and struggling to locate his pitches. While he has been a durable in college and will get the chance to develop as a starter in pro ball, his ultimate role may be as a high-leverage reliever."

mlbp_blurb: "Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 40 | Run: 45 | Arm: 55 | Field: 55 | Overall: 45  One of three Venezuelans to receive seven-figure signing bonuses from the Red Sox in 2017, Flores turned pro for $1.4 million. He's no relation to Daniel Flores, who died of cancer four months after signing for $3.1 million. His tools are fairly similar to those of C.J. Chatham's, Boston's top shortstop prospect, though Flores is much further away from the big leagues.  Though Flores receives more praise for his instincts than his tools, he has the ability to contribute both offensively and defensively. He has good actions at shortstop, where his savvy allows him to cover more ground than his fringy speed would suggest. He has the arm strength for the position, though he needs to be mindful not to drop his arm slot and lose accuracy on his throws.  With a nice right-handed swing and signs of an advanced approach, Flores should hit for average. He's not very physical but has some loft in his stroke and should develop some gap power once he gets stronger. He won't be a basestealer, but runs the bases well."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 35 | Run: 50 | Arm: 60 | Field: 60 | Overall: 45   The 2015 international class is turning into a really good one, led by Vladimir Guerrero Jr. and Fernando Tatis Jr., among other top prospects. The Phillies were active in that class, topped by signing Jhailyn Ortiz for $4 million. They also got Guzman, but for only $60,000, and the organization is very excited for how much the middle infielder has already exceeded expectations.  After a very strong pro debut in the Dominican Summer League in 2016 when he hit .300 with a .370 OBP, Guzman held his own stateside in the Gulf Coast League before running out of gas a bit. His calling cards come on the defensive side of things, a true shortstop who will stay at the position long-term thanks to great hands, a plus arm and excellent instincts for the position. The teenager does have some feel to hit, with a solid approach and the ability to put the ball in play consistently. He currently lacks strength, which limits his ability to impact the baseball offensively.  The Phillies are confident Guzman can play the premium position for a long time. How his bat develops will ultimately determine just what kind of overall impact he makes."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 45 | Run: 40 | Arm: 60 | Field: 50 | Overall: 45  The Guerrero family was well represented on MLB Pipeline's Top 30 Internattional Prospects list heading into the 2015 signing period. Vladimir Guerrero Jr. was No. 7 overall and is now one of the top prospects in all of baseball. His cousin, Gregory, was ranked No. 21 on that list and received $1.5 million from the Mets to sign. While Vlad has moved quickly, Gregory has been slower to develop and is still more about projection than performance.  The Mets are still high on Guerrero's all-around tool package, with the understanding that after a summer in the Dominican and a summer in the Gulf Coast League, he's still very far away. On any given day, you can see the bat speed and physicality developing, with the chance for him to be a solid hitter with Major League average power, though that hasn't shown up in games yet. While he has a strong arm and decent defensive actions, he's not going to play shortstop, the position he was signed at, long-term. He's already seen considerable time at second and could eventually find a home at third, given his below-average speed and strong, physical build.  Before figuring all that out, Guerrero is going to have to start showing he can turn those tools into production. The good news is he's just 19 years old for all of 2018, with plenty of time for it to start clicking."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 30 | Run: 70 | Arm: 40 | Field: 60 | Overall: 45  Machado was ranked No. 16 on MLB Pipeline's Top 30 International Prospects list heading into the 2016 signing period and he was atop the Cardinals' shopping list. The organization spent freely in the market, led by the $2.35 million Machado got to sign. The toolsy outfielder made his United States debut in the Gulf Coast League and would have finished fourth in the Rookie-level circuit in batting average if he had compiled enough at-bats to qualify.  Machado has already shown that he's a tough out at the plate, one with outstanding contact skills. He rarely strikes out and rose to the challenge by battling the better pitching he faced during his U.S. debut. While power is never going to be a large part of his game, Machado does need to add strength so he can continue to impact the baseball against higher levels of competition. He's a plus runner who should be able to steal bases, so an improved approach that includes drawing more walks will help. His speed helps him in the outfield, with enough range to stay in center, though he has a below-average arm.  Just 19 years old, Machado has a long way to go. Added strength and better plate discipline will help him reach his ceiling as a dynamic table-setter who plays up the middle."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 50 | Run: 45 | Arm: 55 | Field: 45 | Overall: 45  Curbelo began his high school career at the Puerto Rican Baseball Academy a year after Carlos Correa departed as the No. 1 overall pick in the 2012 Draft. After performing well on the summer showcase circuit, he moved to Cocoa (Fla.) High as a senior to increase his exposure, though a down spring and strong commitment cause him to slide to the sixth round in 2016. Signed for a well over-slot $700,000 after a strong pre-Draft workout for the White Sox, he played only three games in 2017 before tearing the meniscus in his knee and requiring surgery.   Though Curbelo has hit just .242/.322/.354 in Rookie ball during his first two pro seasons, he projects as an offensive-minded infielder. With the bat speed and leverage he generates from the right side of the plate, the ball jumps off his bat and he could produce 20 homers per season in his prime. He'll need to make more consistent contact to get the most out of his pop, and club officials believe he's intelligent enough to make those adjustments.  All three of Curbelo's games in 2017 came at shortstop, though it's unlikely he'll stay there. He's an average runner who figures to lose a step as he gets stronger, making second base (where he spent most of his debut) the best-case scenario and third base another possibility. He has reliable hands and the arm strength for the hot corner, where his power projection also fits the profile."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 55 | Curveball: 55 | Changeup: 50 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45  When the Brewers acquired Herrera from Seattle as part of the Adam Lind deal in December 2015, the club knew that it was getting a raw, but highly projectable young right-hander. Just 17 at the time and fresh off of his professional debut in the Dominican Summer League, he's since made steady progress, highlighted by a promotion to Class A Wisconsin in 2017.  Herrera has added strength to his wiry frame since signing, but it's his remaining physical projection which has the Brewers excited. His fastball has ticked up into the low 90s consistently, and he continues to show good feel for spinning a breaking ball while also making strides with a changeup. Herrera's control of his arsenal was tested in his first full-season exposure, and he'll need to learn to pitch down in the zone with more consistency to be successful at higher levels.  Herrera joined the Brewers in the same deal that netted the organization fellow right-hander Freddy Peralta. While Peralta has made an impressive rise through Milwaukee's system, Herrera, with added strength and better stuff, could take a similar path."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 40 | Run: 50 | Arm: 50 | Field: 50 | Overall: 45   The younger brother of Padres reliever Phil Maton, Nick began his college career at Eastern Illinois, then transferred to Lincoln Land Community College and re-entered the Draft. A 40th-round pick out of high school, he improved his Draft standing by 33 rounds, with a solid pro debut in the New York-Penn League after the Phillies took him in the seventh round.  Maton has average tools across the board, with the chance to be better than that with the bat. He has an advanced approach from the left side of the plate, draws walks and shows the penchant for consistent line-drive contact. He may never be a big power guy, but there is some extra-base ability and he should run into a few homers along the way.   Defensively, Maton is steady, but many feel he won't stay at shortstop long-term, and he has seen some time at second base during his full-season debut in 2018. If it all comes together, he could be an offensive-minded second baseman, with the possibility of being a lefty-hitting utility type also feasible."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 30 | Run: 70 | Arm: 55 | Field: 60 | Overall: 45  A four-sport athlete as an Iowa high schooler, Ziegler struggled to hit NCAA Division I pitching as a Northern Illinois freshman but batted .395 with 22 homers and 31 steals as a North Iowa Area CC sophomore in 2016. Though junior college offensive numbers don't necessarily have much predictive value, the Giants signed him for $100,000 as a 22nd-rounder because they believed in his speed and defense. He's still raw in all phases of the game, which is why he won't make his full-season debut until 2018.  Some evaluators have clocked Ziegler with top-of-the-scale run times and he builds his game around his well above-average speed. He can steal bases and chase down balls in center field on sheer quickness alone, though he needs to refine his reads and jumps on the bases and in the outfield. His solid arm strength enhances his defensive value.  Ziegler needs to get on base more often to take advantage of his speed. He makes a decent amount of contact from the right side of the plate, but needs to add more strength and patience. His JUCO power doesn't translate to wood bats, though he does have some bat speed and can drive the ball to the gaps on occasion."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 65 | Curveball: 50 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45  Part of the Royals' international spending spree during the summer of 2015, Lara signed for $200,000 out of the Dominican Republic. While he's still making the transition from thrower to pitcher, he has one of the quickest arms in the organization. After two seasons in Rookie ball, he'll make the jump to low Class A in 2018.  Lara already has boosted his fastball from the low 90s when he signed to the mid-90s with a peak of 100 mph two years later, though his heater is fairly straight. He also has some power to a curveball that hovers around 80 mph and sometimes turns into more of a slider when he doesn't stay on top of it. He also has a circle changeup but needs to show more trust in it.  Lara's control and command are very much works in progress. His small, lean frame and the funkiness of his arm action lead to questions about his durability and viability as a starter. Though Kansas City will continue to give him innings in the rotation for now, he could wind up as an upper-90s reliever in the long run."

"Scouting grades:  Hit: 45 | Power: 50 | Run: 40 | Arm: 50 | Field: 55 | Overall: 45  Smith had spent his first two years at Maryland as a starter at shortstop when he headed to Cape Cod for the summer. It was in that elite wood-bat league that he jumped much more firmly onto the Draft radar with an outstanding performance that led to an All-Star selection and playoff MVP honors. He didn't fare as well as a junior, but still earned a third-round selection by Toronto in June. Assigned to Rookie-level Bluefield for his pro debut, Smith continued to intrigue with his power potential while holding his own at a premium position.   A .267 hitter in college who batted .271 during his pro debut, Smith's lack of average is a product of a swing that, while impactful, comes with too much swing-and-miss tendencies. He has shown some aptitude for making adjustments and improving in that regard, something he'll have to do in the pro ranks. He has sneaky right-hander power that he already gets to in games, but while he is capable of driving the ball to all fields, he tends to get too pull-happy and too uphill with his swing. Smith is a below-average runner but has instincts and hands that should allow him to stay at shortstop. His arm grades out as average, but he has a quick release and is always accurate.  There's nothing flashy with Smith's game, but he makes all of the plays consistently. If the bat can improve, he has the chance to be an everyday shortstop at the next level, something the Blue Jays are banking on."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 40 | Run: 50 | Arm: 40 | Field: 45 | Overall: 45  Few college middle infielders in the 2017 Draft could match Netzer's track record of hitting. He won the Cal Ripken League batting title at .349 in the summer of 2015, hit .384 as a UNC Charlotte sophomore in 2016 and compiled a .351 average in three college seasons. His prowess at the plate made him a third-round pick, the fourth-highest in 49ers history, and earned him a slightly below-slot $475,000 bonus. He hit his way to Class A four weeks into his pro career.  Netzer's bat speed and feel for the barrel allow him to make line-drive contact with ease. He walked almost as much as he struck out in college, though he expanded his strike zone in his introduction to pro ball. He has some raw power, though his left-handed swing is relatively flat and geared more for doubles than home runs.  Netzer has average speed, but subpar arm strength, limiting his defensive options. He's an adequate second baseman whose only other position is left field, where he played as a college freshman. His bat-first profile at second base has drawn comparisons to Adam Kennedy and Tommy La Stella."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 40 | Run: 50 | Arm: 60 | Field: 60 | Overall: 45  Signed out of Venezuela back in October 2012, Azocar initially opened eyes by using his tools well in his second season in the Venezuelan Summer League in 2014 and then again during a very successful United States debut. His full-season debut a year later was OK, but he wasn't able to replicate it with a move up to Lakeland in 2017, leaving some evaluators scratching their heads.  After the start to his career here in the States, the Tigers thought Azocar would have gained more traction by now. The key culprit has been a lack of any kind of approach at the plate. There's a lot of swing and miss, he chases pitches out of the zone and drew only 14 walks in 2017 (compared to 122 strikeouts). When he does make contact, it can be loud, and there is some raw power for him to tap into if he can find a way to stop getting himself out. An above-average runner, Azocar has shown he can play center and has a plus arm that looks very good in right.  The Tigers still believe in Azocar's tools. It hasn't clicked for him yet, but they think it will. He's young enough to get headed in the right direction, with an improved approach No. 1 on his priority list."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 45 | Run: 40 | Arm: 40 | Field: 50 | Overall: 45    Stafford had a huge sophomore year at St. Joseph's, then followed up with a strong showing in the Cape Cod League, making him one of the better college catching options heading into his Draft year in 2017. But a rough junior year hurt his stock, making him available in the fifth round for the Pirates, who signed him for just below pick value. Whatever problems Stafford had at St. Joe's weren't apparent during his pro debut as he made the New York-Penn League All-Star team.    Since beginning his Pirates career, Stafford has gotten back to what worked for him before his rough junior campaign. He has shown the ability to make hard contact and the power that was on display as a sophomore and on the Cape has come back, especially to the pull side, though there is some swing and miss to his offensive game. He's a decent receiver, with decent hands and blocking ability, though his arm is below-average at this point. The Pirates like his leadership behind the plate.    There's work to be done on Stafford's defensive game, but the Pirates are committed to allowing him to develop behind the plate. If he can progress there, he has the makings of an offensive-minded backstop who can at least be a serviceable backup at the highest level."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Curveball: 60 | Changeup: 40 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45  Otto could be the Yankees' next success story with converting college relievers into pro starters, following Chance Adams and the since-traded Taylor Widener. A 2017 fifth-rounder signed for $320,900, he made just four starts in three years at Rice, which preferred to use him as a multi-inning reliever. He dealt with a tired arm early in his Draft year before winning Conference USA tournament MVP honors and posting a 1.35 ERA in his brief pro debut.  As a college reliever and in short pro stints, Otto sat at 92-95 mph with his fastball and peaked at 97. His spike curveball can be more devastating and also harder to control, combining power and 12-to-6 break. Both Adams and Widener added velocity and maintained it over a full season after shifting to the rotation, and if that happens with Otto he'll have a pair of well-above-average pitches.  Otto rarely employed a changeup in college, so adding a reliable third pitch will be a focal point of his development. Improving his control and command are also on his to-do list after he averaged 4.5 walks per nine innings at Rice. He has a strong frame and his arm works well, so he should have the durability required to start."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 50 | Run: 45 | Arm: 60 | Field: 50 | Overall: 45    Scouts saw plenty of Abreu when they were scouting Albert Almora (the sixth overall pick in the 2012 Draft) at Mater Academy Charter High (Hialeah Gardens, Fla.), and he had the tools to go in the top five rounds the following year. After he turned down the Reds as a 14th-rounder, he never quite put up big numbers in three years at Miami, though he did help the Hurricanes reach a pair of College World Series. A sixth-round selection in 2016, he hit 14 homers and stole 40 bases in low Class A during his first full pro season.    Abreu's bat speed, strength and leverage create well above-average raw power from the left side of the plate, but he's not going to get to use all of it unless he improves as a hitter. He's overly aggressive, which leads to swing-and-misses and a lot of weak contact on pitches he'd be better off avoiding rather than putting in play. Whether he can make adjustments and provide more consistent pop remains to be seen.    Abreu moves well for a 6-foot-4, 225-pounder but his 40 steals are as much a product of his instincts than his average speed. He has plus arm strength and showed it off by leading the South Atlantic League with 16 outfield assists in 2017. He gets the job done in right field and could fill in for short periods in center."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 30 | Run: 65 | Arm: 45 | Field: 50 | Overall: 45  Injuries really hampered Robson during his career at Mississippi State, though despite a broken hand as a redshirt junior, the Tigers saw enough to pick him in the eighth round of the 2016 Draft. He played well enough in his first full season of pro ball to earn a promotion from the Midwest League up to the Florida State League, finishing third in the system in batting average and fifth in stolen bases.  Robson's best tool is his speed and it allows him to be a basestealing threat as well as a defensive asset in the outfield. He has played all three spots thus far, with his best chance to be a regular coming in center or left, where his fringy arm would be acceptable, and the Tigers feel he could be an above-average defender in time. He has shown a solid approach at the plate and the willingness to draw walks, but for someone with no power to speak of, he will have to cut down on the strikeouts. The Tigers continue to stress bunting as a tool to help him let his legs do the talking.  Robson profiles best as a fourth outfielder or bench presence, one whose speed can do a lot of things. If he can continue to refine his approach and get on base, he could be a table-setting type at the highest level."

"Scouting Grades: Fastball: 45 | Curve: 55 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45  Selected in the 18th round in 2015 out of Michigan State, Misiewicz made steady progress in the Mariners system, opening his first full season at the Class A Advanced level and then advancing to Double-A in June 2017. It was there where he was stationed when Seattle dealt him, Luis Rengifo and a player to be named later to Tampa Bay in August. However, Misiewicz's time with the Rays was short lived, as the Mariners re-acquired the left-hander in December in exchange for international slot money.   Misiewicz stands out more for his pitchability and durability than his stuff. He pitches with an 88-92 mph fastball that has decent life but also plays relatively straight. Misiewicz's curveball is his only above-average pitch, registering in the low 80s with downer action, and he rounds out his three-pitch mix with a low-80s changeup that has late sink as well as some fading action. Meanwhile, Misiewicz's ability to repeat his delivery enables him to throw strikes with consistency, albeit with more control than command.   Though he finished the season with a career-high 141 strikeouts, Misiewicz did miss fewer bats after moving up to Double-A, a trend that likely will continue at higher levels. He's proved plenty durable in the past two seasons, logging 157 2/3 innings and 147 2/3 innings, respectively, and it's that workhorse profile which could help him develop into a No. 5 starter or swingman in the big leagues."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 30 | Run: 55 | Arm: 55 | Field: 60 | Overall: 45  A three-year starter at shortstop for Mississippi, Robinson helped the Rebels make the College World Series as a freshman in 2014 but didn't make much progress with the bat afterward. Posting the worst numbers of his college career during his Draft year dropped him to the sixth round in 2016. He has hit better than anticipated in pro ball and didn't look out of place in Double-A when a shortage of middle infielders necessitated his promotion there last June.  In little more than a year, Robinson has established himself as the best defender among the system's infield prospects. He has nice actions, solid range to both sides, soft hands and the arm to make all of the throws. The Dodgers have given him extensive action at second base to enhance his versatility, and they've also played him briefly at third base and center field.   Even with the good start to his pro career, Robinson still projects to hit at the bottom of a batting order. There's a lot going on in his right-handed swing and though he still manages to make consistent contact, he provides very little in the way of power or walks. He gets the most out of his solid speed on the bases."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 40 | Run: 60 | Arm: 60 | Field: 55 | Overall: 45  Houston tapped Northeastern Oklahoma A&M JC for a pair of Draft picks in 2014, grabbing right-hander Dean Deetz in the 11th round and Laureano in the 16th. Signed for $25,000, Laureano broke out in '16, batting .319/.428/.528 with 15 homers and 43 steals and leading the Minors in on-base percentage. While playing at a launching pad at Class A Advanced Lancaster boosted his numbers, he performed even better in Double-A and continued to stand out in the Arizona Fall League. But after he regressed across the board at Double-A in 2017, hitting .225/.296/.367 in his worst full-season campaign, and with Houston facing a 40-man roster crunch, Laureano become property of the A's in a November trade.   Though he's far from punch-less at the plate, Laureano stands out more for his hitting ability than his power. He has good patience and uses the entire field, though there are growing concerns about how much his simple right-handed swing will translate into power against better pitching. If he can cut down his strikeout rate and regain his once impressive feel for the zone, he could become a high-OBP player with 10-15 homers per year. Even if he doesn't, Laureano's strong track record against left-handed pitching could help him carve out a reserve role.  Provided he can get back on track with his bat, Laureano could fit nicely in the leadoff spot because he pairs his on-base skills with plus speed and the know-how to steal bases. He's more of an average defender in center field, better on the corners and capable of playing all three spots thanks to plus arm strength that produced a Texas League-best 16 assists in 2017."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 40 | Run: 50 | Arm: 50 | Field: 50 | Overall: 45    Not every prospect takes a straight and quick path to the big leagues. Urias was originally signed by the Rangers in December 2010, but after two uneventful summers in the Dominican Summer League, he was first loaned, then sold to Mexico City in the Mexican League. After five seasons of putting up numbers, both in the summer and winter leagues, the Cardinals signed the infielder in January and he made quick work of Double-A, earning a bump to Triple-A in May.    Urias showed an ability to hit for average throughout his Mexican League stay, hitting .300 or better in four of his five seasons. He has a good approach at the plate, he draws walks and doesn't strike out much, all while showing surprising extra-base power for his 5-foot-10 frame. Defensively, he's best suited for second base on a daily basis, but he has shown he can handle short or third when needed.     The type who has consistently outperformed his tools, Urias is a smart overachiever who fits a utility-type profile. The Cardinals took a flier on him and it's looking like they may have found a future bench player for their big league roster."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 55 | Curveball: 50 | Changeup: 55 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45  Johnson flew under the radar at Cal State Northridge, missing most of his first two seasons with an elbow injury and subsequent Tommy John surgery and logging a 4.33 ERA as a redshirt sophomore in 2014. He created a stir in his first extended pro action the following year, flashing electric stuff while posting a 71/11 K/BB ratio across three levels. He hasn't been able to sustain that kind of success since, never getting into a rhythm in Double-A last season while losing a month to a hamstring injury.  Johnson still can flash a three-pitch mix that seems to stamp him as a starter. At his best, he can sit at 92-96 mph with sink on his fastball, confound hitters with plus changeups that tumble and offer some curveballs with power and depth. But he doesn't show that kind of stuff consistently because he collapses on the backside of his delivery, flattening his pitches and leaving them up in the strike zone.  While the Giants hold out hope that Johnson can improve his mechanics and become more consistent, they also declined to protect him on their 40-man roster after the 2017 season. He spent most of the season working with a 90-94 mph fastball while his control also regressed. If he doesn't start displaying more consistency, a bullpen move could be in his near future."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 55 | Run: 30 | Arm: 55 | Field: 50 | Overall: 45  There have been two certain things about Cron since he came out of TCU as a 14th-round pick in 2014: He has a ton of power and comes from a family steeped in the game of baseball. The younger brother of C.J. and son of former professional player and coach Chris has now hit at least 25 home runs in each of his three full seasons of pro ball. Improvements in his approach led to even better offensive results in Double-A in 2017, leading to him earning Southern League MVP honors.  At 6-foot-5, 245 pounds, Cron's strength is obvious, and his raw power is at least plus. Swing-and-miss issues and a lack of plate discipline had previously held him back and forced him to repeat at Double-A in 2017. His pitch recognition improved tremendously in his second go-round in the Southern League, with the increase in walks helping to offset what will always be a healthy strikeout total. With his size and below-average speed, Cron is a little limited defensively, but he has good hands and the D-backs actually think he's deceptively strong as a fielder. He has a strong arm and could even see a little time at third in 2018.  It will be Cron's bat that gets him to The Show, and the power will have to keep showing up for him to be a regular first baseman in the big leagues. The D-backs didn't protect Cron on the 40-man roster last offseason, but he went unselected in the Rule 5 Draft. He'll try to show the organization he deserves a spot in 2018."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Slider: 50 | Curveball: 40 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 50 | Overall: 45  Even since his days at the University of Virgnia, Lewicki has shown the aptitude to get hitters out, but staying healthy has always been an issue. He had Tommy John surgery at Virginia in 2013. The right-hander missed two months of his first full pro season with a pectoral muscle injury. The 2016 season saw more of the same, with Lewicki getting shelved for six weeks. A healthy 2017 at the upper levels, however, set him up for his first big league callup last September.  Lewicki has shown feel for four pitches at times, all of which he can throw for strikes. His fastball might typically sit around 92 mph, but he gets it up to 95 mph with regularity, throwing it with good sink. His slider will flash above-average and he'll also show an average changeup at times, albeit inconsistently, while mixing in a curveball as well. He doesn't miss a ton of bats, but he also doesn't hurt himself that much with walks.  Lewicki had worked some in relief at Virginia, and while he has largely started throughout his Minor League career, he pitched out of the bullpen for Detrot last September (with one start mixed in) and served the same role when he was summoned from Triple-A in 2018. His fastball-slider combination could continue to play up should he stay in a relief gig long-term."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 55 | Run: 45 | Arm: 55 | Field: 40 | Overall: 45  Palka led the Atlantic Coast Conference with 17 homers in 2013 and even contributed a 0.69 ERA in 13 innings on the mound before signing with the Diamondbacks as a third-round pick that June. He smashed 51 homers in two full seasons in Arizona's system before getting traded to the Twins for Chris Herrmann in November 2015, then went deep 34 times in his first year as a Minnesota farmhand. A broken left index finger cost Palka seven weeks last season and affected his power when he returned, and the White Sox claimed him on waivers when the Twins took him off their 40-man roster last November.  Palka's bat speed and strength give him considerable raw power from the left side of the plate, and it translates into game production. However, he employs an all-or-nothing approach that resulted in a 27 percent strikeout rate in his first five pro seasons, so there's concern about his ability to make consistent contact against big league pitching. Palka does show a willingness to draw walks, so he could post respectable on-base percentages despite subpar batting averages.  Palka will have to keep mashing to claim and hold onto a big league role, because he doesn't offer much beyond his offense. Despite fringy speed and solid arm strength, he doesn't cover much ground and is a liability on the outfield corners. Palka broke into pro ball as a first baseman and can provide adequate defense there."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 65 | Slider: 55 | Curveball: 50 | Changeup: 40 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45  Though Wolff continually showed promise as a power arm after joining the Rangers as a sixth-round senior sign out of New Mexico in 2013, he couldn't stay healthy. He missed all of 2015 after tearing his left Achilles tendon, the last three months of 2016 with a right forearm strain and the final month of 2017 with a torn flexor tendon in his right hand. Traded to the Giants with fellow righty prospect Israel Cruz for Matt Moore and $750,000 in international bonus pool funds last December, he'll miss the start of this season as well.  Wolff's arm speed generates mid-90s fastballs with some armside run when he comes out of the bullpen, and he has been clocked as high as 100 mph. He still has a four-pitch repertoire from his days as a starter, with his slider his best secondary offering. He'll also mix in a curveball but rarely uses his changeup as a reliever.  After Texas made Wolff a full-time reliever last year, he struck out 59 in 43 innings and was pushing for his first big league callup until he got hurt again in August. His control has regressed since he began dealing with the litany of injuries, but he could fill a seventh-inning role if he can provide consistent strikes."
