mlbd_blurb: "Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 50 | Run: 30 | Arm: 45 | Field: 45 | Overall: 45  Gulliver Prep in the Miami area has had five players taken in the top five rounds, the most recent being infielder Adrian Marin, a third-rounder in 2012 currently in the Orioles organization. Del Castillo might be next on that list, though his bat-over-glove profile may keep him from reaching Marin's spot.    Scouts universally like Del Castillo's swing from the left side of the plate. He recognizes pitches well, with a solid game plan, and should be able to hit for average. Because he doesn't expand the zone, he drives good hitters' pitches and has plenty of raw power to tap into. His work behind the plate remains behind what he can do in the batter's box. His arm is fringy, though it tends to be accurate, and his receiving skills will need continued refinement at the next level. If there was a need to move him out behind the plate, some feel left field would be the most suitable position for him.    Del Castillo has a strong commitment to the University of Miami, so it might be tough to sign him beyond a certain round or bonus figure. Any team that makes a run at him will be buying the bat along with the hope that his defensive work improves so he can stay behind the plate, maximizing his value."

mi_blurb: "Age 21, seventh round pick in 2017 from State Junior College of Florida; posted 2.58 ERA with 36/16 K/BB in 38 innings in NY-P; more projectable than the typical college pitcher with 6-5, 170 frame that can still fill out; 93-95 fastball, both change-up and curveball have potential to be at least average; command needs more work but upside of a number three starter. ETA 2021."
mlbp_blurb: "Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Curveball: 55 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 40 | Overall: 45  Tetreault spent his freshman year at Cameron University (Okla.) before transferring to State College of Florida Manatee - Sarasota ahead of his sophomore campaign. He showed improved stuff as a member of the starting rotation that spring, and the Nationals, intrigued by his present ability and potential, drafted him in the seventh round. After signing for above-slot at $300,000 and forgoing a South Florida commitment, Tetreault had a successful pro debut between the Rookie-level Gulf Coast and Class A Short-Season New York-Penn Leagues.   Listed at 6-foot-5, 170 pounds, Tetreault has considerable physical projection remaining. His stuff is plenty good, too, as the quick-armed right-hander will reach 95 mph with his fastball while flashing a sharp, above-average curveball and showing feel for a changeup. Tetreault has considerable physical projection remaining, though some scouts do worry about his ability to maintain velocity and work deep into games.  Given his limited college track record and remaining physical projection, it shouldn't come as a surprise that Tetreault's control and command are both below average. The Nationals, however, are excited about his upside, viewing him as a late-bloomer who has the potential to stick in the starting rotation."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 50 | Run: 30 | Arm: 55 | Field: 45 | Overall: 45    The Cardinals didn't have a pick until the third round of the 2017 Draft because of their free-agent signing of Dexter Fowler and the hacking scandal with the Astros. They did try to strategically use their small bonus pool and went over pick value to sign Jackson out of the Florida high school ranks, and away from playing for the Florida Gators, in the sixth round. He played sparingly on a Gulf Coast League roster that had two other catchers on it during his pro debut.    Jackson is a left-handed-hitting catcher, something always in demand, one with power potential at the plate and a power arm behind it. He's capable of making loud contact with solid bat speed and while there's swing and miss potential, he draws walks and can drive the ball, with the chance for future Major League power. His arm will flash plus at times and he threw out 31.5 percent of potential basestealers during his debut, albeit in a very small sample size, He's not overly athletic or agile, so he'll have to work on his overall receiving.    Jackson will get his Cardinals career going in earnest in 2018, with reps and time needed, as they are for any high school backstop to develop."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 50 | Slider: 50 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45    Vargas initially signed with the D-backs back in January 2013, and to say it's been a slow development process would be a bit of an understatement. The Dominican right-hander spent two summers in the Dominican Summer League before making his United States debut in '15. He made his full-season debut the following year, a summer that included a 17-strikeout performance in August, though he repeated the level in '17. Things looked like they were starting to click, however, with a move to the California League this season.    The 6-foot-3 right-hander has a good pitcher's frame and some solid stuff to go along with it. Vargas features a fastball he throws in the 90-94 mph range that he maintains throughout his start. His slider has improved and now gives him a solid breaking ball that misses bats. He also has a developing changeup that he mixes in effectively. While Vargas has been tougher to hit and his strikeout rate has gone up, so has his walk rate, and he is more control over command with his arsenal at this point.    Even with his slow progress, Vargas is still young for his level and there's no reason for the D-backs to lose patience given the step forward he's taken. He has a ceiling as a back-end starter, though he could look awfully good with that fastball-slider combination in a shorter relief role."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 40 | Power: 55 | Run: 40 | Arm: 50 | Field: 40 | Overall: 45  Gilliam has diverse athletic bloodlines, as he's the grandson of former National League Rookie of the Year Jim Gilliam and also is related to former NBA power forward Armen Gilliam and former NFL quarterback Joe Gilliam. He reclassified to enter the Draft a year early in 2014, turning down the Cubs as a 23rd-rounder before signing with the Yankees for $550,000 as a 20th-rounder out of Chipola (Fla.) JC the following June. He spent his first two pro seasons in Rookie ball before hitting 15 homers in low Class A in 2017.  A switch-hitter, Gilliam has some of the best raw power in New York's system and does more damage from the right side. He's strong and has plenty of bat speed, leverage and loft in his swing, but he will have to show he can make consistent contact in order to tap into his pop. Gilliam made strides with his approach and discipline last year but has been overly aggressive in 2018.  Gilliam has to produce at the plate because he doesn't offer much value on the bases or in the field. He's a below-average runner and corner outfielder, though he does have some arm strength. He may be best suited for first base, which would put even more pressure on his bat."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 50 | Run: 30 | Arm: 45 | Field: 45 | Overall: 45  Skoug could have gone in the first three rounds of the 2014 Draft if he hadn't been intent on attending Texas Christian, where he immediately became the Horned Frogs' cleanup hitter and led them to three College World Series in three years. In 2017, he overcame an early slump and 98 strikeouts (one short of the NCAA record) to share the Big 12 Conference player of the year award after leading the league with 20 homers and 71 RBI. He slid to the seventh round of the Draft, where the White Sox pounced on him with an over-slot $300,000 bonus.  Skoug has impressive bat speed and strength that create plus raw power. He's at his best when he employs a compact left-handed swing, uses the entire field and lets his pop come naturally, but he fell into a rut at the beginning of his Draft year where his stroke got too long and he got too pull-happy while trying to do to much. He struck out in 38 percent of his plate appearances during his brief pro debut, and while fatigue played a part, he'll need to make adjustments to handle more advanced pitching.  Though no one questions Skoug's leadership work ethic, there are concerns about his ability to stay behind the plate. He lacks athleticism and quickness, limiting his effectiveness as a receiver, and might wind up at first base. He compensates for fringy arm strength with a quick release."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 30 | Run: 55 | Arm: 60 | Field: 60 | Overall: 45  Many evaluators tabbed Martin as the top defensive shortstop in the 2015 Draft class before the A's made him the No. 20 overall pick and signed him for $1.95 million. While he's mostly lived up to that reputation in the pro ranks, Martin's bat remains a work in progress. Knee surgery to repair a torn meniscus sidelined Martin early in his first full season, and he produced uneven results at the plate in the Class A Advanced California League once finally healthy before a late-season promotion to Double-A Midland based on his defensive merits. Returning to the Texas League in 2017, Martin's offensive woes deepened. He mustered just a .224 average in 86 games in Texas League, prompting a demotion from the A's back to Stockton. Martin began 2018 in extended spring training as he recovers from his second offseason knee surgery in the past three years to repair a torn meniscus.  Martin's impressive range at shortstop is a product of his athleticism and above-average speed, and scouts rave about his first-step quickness as well as his overall instincts. His arm is a clean fit at the position and enables him to make highlight-reel plays, but he's also capable of getting rid of the ball quickly while on the move, without sacrificing any accuracy.  There's still some hope for Martin's bat, but his .235 average and .330 slugging percentage in his first three seasons certainly is not what the A's were expecting. He shows good bat-to-ball skills, doesn't strike out much and reaches base at a solid clip. His right-handed swing, however, yields excessive weak contact, as he all too often rolls over balls on the ground while offering little in the way of gap power, let alone over-the-fence pop. Martin's defense can still carry him to the big leagues, but not without a modicum of improvement at the plate."

mi_blurb: "Age 18, 17th round pick in 2017 from high school in Kennewick, Washington; hit .307/.457/.630 in rookie ball with 11 homers, 32 walks, 41 strikeouts in 127 at-bats; signed for overslot $350,000 bonus to keep him away from college at Gonzaga; advocates like his power and plate discipline combination, while skeptics point to poor defense and a non-projectable 6-1, 205 pound body; the first name that popped in my head was Greg Bird of the Yankees, although Martin is very different physically, Bird being 6-4, 220; despite the physical difference, it is possible that Martin could sneak up on us the way that Bird did; keep an eye out; ETA 2022"
mlbp_blurb: "Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 50 | Run: 30 | Arm: 45 | Field: 40 | Overall: 45  As teams get to the later rounds of the Draft, they rely heavily on the area scouts, who put in the work to really know players and finding value. The Pirates leaned on Pacific Northwest scout Max Kwan, who was on Martin's offensive upside from the get-go and knew what it would take to sign him. The Pirates gave Martin well above the $100,000 threshold in the 17th round to sign him away from his Gonzaga commitment and he promptly went out and led the Gulf Coast League in home runs, on-base percentage and slugging.  Martin impressed immediately, and throughout his pro debut, with his professional at-bats. He has an advanced approach from the left side of the plate, particularly for a high schooler, drawing walks and not even giving in to left-handers on the mound. He has the chance to be at least an average hitter with above-average power if this continues, and was hitting balls over the center field wall in Pirate City during instructs. The son of a body builder, Martin is no stranger to the weight room and could approach plus power eventually.  A well below-average runner, Martin played some outfield during his pro debut, but he is likely a first baseman only long term, with work to do to be adequate defensively. It will be his bat that carries him, however, with some anticipation to see what he does with it in his first full season."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 35 | Run: 45 | Arm: 55 | Field: 55 | Overall: 45  A former shortstop who blossomed into the best catcher on the 2016-17 international market, Garcia signed out of Venezuela for $800,000. Despite adding 25 pounds in the year before joining the Rangers, he's still not very strong and struggled with the rigors of catching and pro ball during his 2017 debut. He batted just .215/.321/.280 as a 17-year-old in the Rookie-level Dominican Summer League, though his defense was as good as advertised.  Garcia is currently less advanced than Jose Trevino, who's seven years older than him, but eventually could surpass Trevino as the best defender among Texas' deep group of catching prospects. He's quicker and more athletic than most backstops, has soft hands and projects as at least a solid receiver and thrower once he matures physically. He possesses advanced instincts for someone who began catching in 2015.  A switch-hitter, Garcia was helpless against left-handers in his debut and won't do any damage until he adds some much-needed muscle. He's equipped to make line-drive contact with his compact swing but may never have more than gap power. He's presently a fringy runner but will lose a step as he fills out and spends more time behind the plate."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 20 | Run: 55 | Arm: 55 | Field: 60 | Overall: 45    Part of the Blue Jays' 2014-15 international class, Vicuna signed for $350,000 and made his professional debut the next year in the Dominican Summer League. The Venezuela native has since blossomed into one of the finest defenders in Toronto's system, so much so that he was called on to handle shortstop duties for Class A Advanced Dunedin from April 23 to June 1. Vicuna otherwise spent his season showcasing his defense and hitting ability in the Class A Short Season Northwest League before a mid-August promotion to Class A Lansing.    Vicuna's abilities as a shortstop are obvious. He's ultra athletic in his actions, at times flashy, with quick, twitchy hands that help him absorb anything hit his way and execute a quick release, causing his average arm strength to play. Vicuna, like many young shortstops, can be error prone at times, but consistency should come more naturally for him once he has better feel for controlling his body.    Vicuna's bat lags well behind his glove. He's punchless from the right side of the plate, with little extra-base pop despite good bat-to-ball skills and a sound approach. Gaining strength as he grows into his lithe frame should do wonders for Vicuna's offensive game, but he'll still be a glove-first player."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 30 | Run: 60 | Arm: 50 | Field: 50 | Overall: 45  Originally a fifth-round pick of the Mariners out of East Carolina in 2013, Reinheimer joined the D-backs organization courtesy of the June 2015 Mark Trumbo trade. Since then he's shown a willingness and aptitude to move around the field and do the little things well, showing enough to earn his first big league callup in 2017.  Reinheimer has a reputation of being a scrappy gamer who contributes more than his tools say he should. While that's far from faint praise, he's more athletic than people give him credit for. His speed allows him to have more range defensively than many think, regardless of what position he plays. While he's played far more shortstop than anywhere else, and he's capable there, he slides over to second when needed without any difficulty. His time in the Arizona Fall League has helped him add to his versatility, with him continuing to work on playing third, and he even saw some time in the outfield in Triple-A as well.  Reinheimer knows who he is as a hitter, with advanced plate discipline and a willingness to draw walks, albeit without much power. His ticket to a long big league career will likely be to bounce around the field quite a bit, but he's the kind of utility man a team would be comfortable sending out every day at short or second should the need arise."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 30 | Run: 60 | Arm: 60 | Field: 65 | Overall: 45    It looked like the Reds were going to sign Rodriguez, as they were attached to the Cuban shortstop almost from the minute he became eligible to be signed. It took a little longer than expected, but they finally got their man at the start of the 2016 signing period for a bonus of $7 million. During his full-season debut in the Florida State League, Rodriguez both lived up to his defensive reputation and down to concerns about his potential with the bat.    It wasn't all bad offensively for the middle infielder as he wasn't overwhelmed in a pitching-friendly environment and he did hit .270 in the first half before running out of gas. More than anything, Rodriguez needs to refine his approach, learning the strike zone better and working counts more. He does have some raw power to tap into and he needs to try to do more damage rather than just playing for contact.    On the other side of the ball, the Reds feel Rodriguez is one of the best defensive shortstops in the Minors. He has tremendous instincts and a strong arm, making all of the routine plays and then frequently making a play you don't expect he can. Those skills alone should get him to the big leagues, but he's going to have to hit a bit more to be an all-around regular."

mi_blurb: "Age 22, third round pick in 2017 from William and Mary; posted 2.45 ERA with 22/7 K/BB in 51 innings in New York-Penn League, 56 hits; strikeout rate was much higher in college and it may come back, low walk rate was nice to see; fastball 90-95, sometimes higher, with good movement low in zone; good change-up but slider needs more polish; remains to be seen if he starts or relieves in long run. ETA 2021."
mlbp_blurb: "Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Curveball: 50 | Slider: 50 | Changeup: 55 | Control: 40 | Overall: 45  Raquet sat out all of 2016 after transferring to William & Mary from North Carolina, where he had appeared in just 12 games out of the bullpen as a freshman. The redshirt sophomore pitched to mixed results in his first season with The Griffin but showed enough arm strength and stuff to warrant a third-round selection by the Nationals.   A physically strong and durable left-hander, Raquet operates in the low-to-mid 90s with his fastball and can reach back for 96 mph, all while maintaining his velocity deep into games. His changeup is his best secondary offering, one that receives above-average grades from scouts, and he also features a pair of average breaking balls in a curveball and a slider.   After missing plenty of bats but struggling to throw strikes as an amateur, Raquet pitched to opposite results during his pro debut. Learning to repeat his delivery as well as harnessing his stuff and throwing more strikes would bode well for his chances of remaining a starter, although there's little doubt among scouts that Raquet could move quickly in a bullpen role."

mi_blurb: "Age 23, 11th round pick in 2016 from Brigham Young University; hit .308/.373/.403 between Low-A, High-A, and Double-A with 43 walks, 100 strikeouts, 20 steals in 491 at-bats; above-average running speed and good defensive instincts are positives; has some pop to the gaps but not likely to be a big home run guy and needs to work on maximizing his on-base abilities; ETA 2019."
mlbp_blurb: "Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 30 | Run: 60 | Arm: 45 | Field: 50 | Overall: 45    Lund was a performer at Brigham Young University for three years, though did so mostly under the radar. The Angels feel fortunate to have gotten him in the 11th round of the 2016 Draft. The type of over-achiever who would have to prove himself at each level, Lund started to do so quickly in his first full season in 2017, beginning the year in the Class A Midwest League and finishing it up two levels in Double-A.    If everything continues to click for Lund, he could be the type of hitter who helps set the table at the top of a lineup. He typically has a solid approach at the plate, making consistent line-drive contact and drawing walks to get on base. He lost sight of that philosophy once he got to Double-A (33 K's, three walks in 29 games) and his strikeout rate did go up with each promotion, so he'll have to make sure he stays true to himself as he advances, as there's no real power for him to rely on. He is a very good runner who knows how to steal a base. That speed also serves him well defensively, where he's shown he can handle all three outfield positions.    That versatility should come in handy, as Lund's offensive profile looks more like one of a fourth outfielder in the future. He does have a high baseball IQ and plus makeup, so underselling him could be a mistake."

mi_blurb: "Age 23, second round pick in 2012 from high school in Georgia; has been on prospect lists for years now but still young; 4.43 ERA with 98/50 K/BB in 138 innings in Double-A, 130 hits; on the right day looks like a number two starter with fastball up to 97, double-plus curveball, workable change-up; on the wrong day he looks like, well, not very good, with fastball velocity sagging, flat change-up and a loopy, mediocre curve; this has been his pattern since he signed and I have no idea if it will change; watch for any improvement in K/BB ratio; ETA late 2018."
mlbp_blurb: "Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Curveball: 50 | Cutter: 45 | Changeup: 50 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45    Underwood hit 98 mph with his fastball and flashed a hammer curveball as a high school senior in 2012, yet he lasted until the second round of the Draft because the consistency of his stuff and command wavered. Six years after he signed for $1,050,000, that remains the case. He dominated in the first three months of 2015 in high Class A but has rarely done so since coming down with a sore elbow that June.    Though Underwood led the Double-A Southern League with 13 victories and worked a career-high 138 innings in 2017, he recorded just seven quality starts in 24 tries. He maintained the velocity on his 92-97 mph fastball but it had less life than usual and he struggled to locate it where he wanted. His secondary pitches weren't as sharp as they had been in the past, with his curveball continuing to rank ahead of his changeup and cutter.    Even when he has premium stuff, Underwood gets hit harder than he should because he doesn't command his pitches. He missed chunks of the 2015 and 2016 seasons with elbow and forearm inflammation and has frustrated the Cubs at times with his lack of dedication. They're still hoping he can become a mid-rotation starter, though it may be time to simplify things and make him a reliever."

mi_blurb: "Age 24, Cuban defector signed for $1,600,000 in 2015; hit .265/.323/.400 in Double-A with eight homers, 25 walks, 48 strikeouts in 310 at-bats; missed almost two months with a finger/hand injury; every time I see him play he hits the crap out of the ball, going 4-for-5 or something while showing above-average bat speed and lashing everything into the gaps; in aggregate however hes been solid rather than excellent; same goes for his glove; scouts dont give his range or arm strength anything more than so-so grades but he makes few mistakes and catches what he gets to, making just five errors in 70 games in 17 for example; could put up big numbers in the Pacific Coast League; ETA late 2018."
mlbp_blurb: "Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 40 | Run: 45 | Arm: 50 | Field: 45 | Overall: 45  The youngest player (age 19) on Cuba's 2013 World Baseball Classic squad, Ibanez established himself as one of the best young hitters in the island's top league before defecting in 2014. Signed for $1.6 million in July 2015, he made his pro debut in 2016 after a two-year layoff and immediately hit .324/.413/.546 in low Class A. His offensive numbers dipped following a promotion to Double-A that June and didn't rebound in 2017, though he has hit the ball with more authority in Triple-A this season.  Ibanez's best tool is his bat and the hope was that he might develop along the lines of Howie Kendrick. He uses a compact right-handed swing to make repeated line-drive contact. He has gap power and the potential for double-digit home run totals, but his ability to put the ball in play so easily cuts into his walk totals.  Though Ibanez won Cuba's equivalent of a Gold Glove as an 18-year-old in 2011, he's merely a defender with fringy speed and average arm strength. He has seen action at third base but doesn't have the power desired at that position. His utility value is limited because he lacks the tools to play shortstop on more than an emergency basis."

mi_blurb: "Age 25, posted 4.41 ERA, 128/57 K/BB in 159 innings in Triple-A, 177 hits; throws harder than Merritt with low-90s fastball and a plus breaking ball, but change-up and overall command still inconsistent; watch for any improvement in K/BB ratio, spike in strikeouts, or both. ETA 2018."
mlbp_blurb: "Scouting grades: Fastball: 50 | Curveball: 45 | Slider: 60 | Changeup: 50 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45  The Indians made Morimando their 19th-round pick in 2011, and then went well above slot to lure him away from his East Carolina commitment. One of the younger starters at every level at which he's pitched in his career, the left-hander made the jump from Double-A Akron to the Major Leagues and made his debut coming out of the Indians' bullpen in July 2016. Returning to a starting role with Triple-A Columbus in 2017, Morimando led the International League in innings (159 1/3), complete games (4) and shutouts (3), while also finishing seventh in strikeouts (128) and tied for seventh in wins (10).  Morimando's fastball sits in the low 90s with good arm-side run, especially when working down in the zone. When working up, however, the left-hander can be very hittable and prone to surrendering home runs. His plus slider is a legitimate out pitch, thrown in the low 80s with hard downer action, and he's also adept at mixing in an average changeup and a fringy curveball. Morimando misses his share of bats, though many of those strikeouts are offset by his below-average command.   Morimando has proved plenty durable in career, as the 2017 season marked his fourth straight campaign with at least 150 innings pitched. He needs to make additional gains with control and command to remain a starter. If he can't, Morimando's fastball-slider combo could play up in a bullpen role."

mlbd_blurb: "Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Slider: 50 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45  Montverde High School in Florida is best known for producing Indians All-Star Francisco Lindor and the school's senior class this year is headlined by shortstop Nander De Sedas. With a strong spring, Wright has been grabbing some of that spotlight as he aims to become the first pitcher drafted from the school.    There's a lot to like in this 6-foot-5 right-hander's stuff, starting with his pure arm strength. Wright has been up to 96 mph at times this spring, though he usually sits in the 91-92 mph range and hasn't always held his velocity deep into his starts. He doesn't always use his lower half effectively and doing so should allow him to maintain his velo. He throws an average slider that has three-quarter tilt to it when it's on, but often looks more like a hard slurve. Like many high school pitchers, his changeup is developing.    Size and arm strength can't be taught and both are boxes scouts check off when it comes to Wright. Some mechanical adjustments could help him take off at the next level, with perhaps enough to work with to sign him away from his Louisville commitment."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 40 | Power: 45 | Run: 60 | Arm: 60 | Field: 50 | Overall: 45  It seems more often than not, prospects who play shortstop in college have to move to another position when they begin their pro careers. Pena is an exception to that rule as an infielder who definitely can stick at the premium position. How much a team believes he'll hit will ultimately determine his Draft status.    A product of the Providence, Rhode Island high school ranks who went on to the University of Maine, Pena profiles as a solid to plus defender who can play shortstop at any level. He has good speed that leads to excellent range and possesses the strong arm and footwork necessary to excel at the demanding position. At the plate, Pena does have some strength and raw power, enough where some see 15 homers annually as a reasonable projection. But that's only if he makes enough consistent contact to reach that power. There's length to his right-handed swing, which leads to some swing and miss issues that can result in an overly aggressive approach.    Some of the mechanics issues can be corrected once he gets to pro ball, and shortening him up will likely be a primary objective for whatever team drafts him. With his defensive profile, being able to unlock a more consistent bat could produce an everyday big league shortstop."

mlbp_blurb: "Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 40 | Run: 50 | Arm: 55 | Field: 55 | Overall: 45  Gonzalez was ranked No. 19 on MLB Pipeline's Top 30 International prospects list heading into the 2017 July 2 signing period. His overall tools, particularly at shortstop, stood out enough for the Tigers to give him $1 million to sign and he's starting his pro career in 2018.  While player and organization are still getting to know each other, Gonzalez has already made an impression with his glove-work. He has very good actions and a strong arm to go along with outstanding hands, giving him the chance to be an above-average to plus defender when all is said and done. Some felt he might need to move to third in the future because of his age.  It's going to take a long time to see if the investment in Gonzalez pays off for Detroit. But the teenager does have all the makings of a big league middle infielder."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 40 | Run: 50 | Arm: 55 | Field: 55 | Overall: 45  The Royals exceeded their international bonus pool for the first time during the 2015-16 signing period, with outfielder Seuly Matias ($2.25 million) and Guzman ($1.5 million) receiving their two biggest bonuses. Part of the same Dominican youth league that spawned Nomar Mazara and Amed Rosario, he batted just .228/.301/.305 in his two years in Rookie ball. Kansas City still likes his potential on both sides of the ball and is encourage that he finished 2017 with his best month as a pro and a strong performance in instructional league.  While he has yet to produce much at the plate, Guzman already recognizes pitches and controls the strike zone well for a teenager. A switch-hitter, he has bat speed but needs more strength in order to do some damage. Though he has a groundball-oriented swing, he should grow into some gap power.  Though he's not flashy, Guzman has good hands and a solid arm that plays up with a quick release at shortstop. He doesn't have the speed or quickness typical of his position, but the Royals believe his smooth actions will allow him to remain there. They like his maturity and how he has handled adversity in his introduction to pro ball."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Curveball: 50 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45    The Reds knew that patience would be key in developing Hanson after drafting him in the third round of the 2016 Draft. He was, after all, a raw high school arm from a cold weather state in Minnesota. The big right-hander taken in the third round and signed away from his Kentucky commitment was delayed even further when he needed Tommy John surgery and missed the entire 2017 season.    The good news is Hanson is back throwing and on pace to play for a short-season club in 2018. He also used his time rehabbing to trim down his 6-foot-6 frame. There's a lot of fastball to come from Hanson, assuming he bounces back to pre-surgery levels, as he was up to 95-96 mph at times with his heater. He also featured a power curve that flashed plus and a changeup that was behind since he didn't need it much in the Minnesota high school ranks. Command was an issue for Hanson, as he struggled to repeat his delivery consistently.    The Reds are pleased with where Hanson is in his rehab process and look forward to getting him back on a mound in competition this summer. It'll be slow going, especially at the start, but the payoff, given his size and chance for two plus pitches, could be big."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Curveball: 50 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45  In July 2016, the Cardinals did some serious shopping on the international market, going heavy on Cuban imports and handing out four seven-figure bonuses in the process. Randy Arozarena and Jonathan Machado landed ahead of Oviedo, who got $1.9 million to sign, on the Top 30. Oviedo's United States debut in 2017 was a bit uneven, but there's still a lot to like in the young right-hander.  It starts with his size, as he is a huge physical specimen at 6-foot-6. His fastball hasn't quite ticked back up to where it was when he was up to 96-97 mph shortly after signing, but there's plenty there, sitting in the 92-94 mph range and touching a bit higher. He uses his size to throw downhill with average movement, showing an early ability to get groundball outs. His curve and changeup are both developing along with his command. The Cardinals think there's an above-average breaking ball in there, while his change remains a work in progress.  More than anything Oviedo needs to work on getting his huge frame in sync and repeating his delivery. That should lead to more consistent strike-throwing along with a refinement of his overall stuff. Patience may be key, but pitching all year at age 20, there's plenty of time for him to figure it out."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 50 | Run: 35 | Arm: 55 | Field: 50 | Overall: 45  A two-time Gatorade player of the year in Utah, Henry was headed for Brigham Young before the Brewers made him their sixth-round pick in the 2016 Draft and signed him for $550,600, nearly twice the recommended value for his slot. He showed promise on both sides of the ball the following year in the Rookie-level Pioneer League and continued to make strides in 2018 with the move up to the Class A Wisconsin.  Henry's physical strength allows him to generate above-average raw power from the right side of the plate, and he's already shown some feel for applying it during games. While there is present swing-and-miss to his game, as well as some pull-side tendencies, Henry has an advanced approach that nets him walks and suggests he'll hit for average as he matures. He's a solid defender with above-average arm strength behind the plate, where he consistently posts Major League-quality pop times despite inconsistent footwork.   Right-handed power may be Henry's calling card, but he has the makings of becoming a well-rounded backstop capable of contributing on both sides of the ball. He'll need time to refine his swing, approach and defensive skills, but the final product could be that of an everyday catcher at the highest level."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 50 | Run: 40 | Arm: 55 | Field: 45 | Overall: 45  Ramos jumped on the radar a bit in 2016 after scuffling during his U.S. debut the prior summer, finishing among the Pioneer League leaders in several offensive categories. He hit well in a step up to the Northwest League in 2017, albeit with less power, earning a promotion to the full-season Midwest League.    Ramos has plus-plus raw power from the right side of the plate, but aside from the outburst with Missoula, it hasn't shown up in games consistently just yet. He was a better overall hitter in 2017, with fewer strikeouts, and the D-backs love the mechanics of his swing. The next step is for him to learn how to control his effort throughout his swing and be able to find that balance between being a solid hitter and tapping into that power. A below-average runner, Ramos is a fringy defender at third, though he does have a very strong arm. He's an average defender at first.    Ramos will continue to see time at both infield corners moving forward, as much to make sure his bat is in the lineup as anything else. It's easy to dream of him fitting the infield corner profile from a run production standpoint, but it's going to take time for him to get there."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 55 | Cutter: 50 | Curveball: 50 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45  The Red Sox signed Almonte back in July 2012 as one of the more intriguing pitchers in that summer's international amateur class. He made slow and steady progress, reaching full-season ball in 2016 before getting sent to the D-backs in the Brad Ziegler deal that July.    Almonte's first full season with his new organization was a solid one, finishing sixth in the system in ERA and third in strikeouts while pitching in the typically hitting-friendly California League. Everything the right-hander throws moves, starting with a fastball that is average velocity-wise -- sitting low-90s most of the time -- but plays up because of its natural cutting action. On top of that, he also throws a cutter-like slider, or slider-like cutter, depending on your point of view that can be really nasty at times, flashing at least above-average. He'll mix in an average curveball and a fringy changeup as well.     Almonte will have to continue to refine his command for him to remain a starter long-term, though he did cut his walk rate considerably in the second half of 2017. He'll try to build momentum off of that as he reaches the upper levels of the system."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Curveball: 55 | Changeup: 40 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45    Signed for $115,000 out of the Dominican Republic in 2012, Gomez spent his first three seasons in pro ball in the Rookie-level Dominican Summer League. He hasn't had much statistical success since coming to the United States in 2016 and led the low Class A South Atlantic League with 12 losses in his full-season debut last year. Nevertheless, he has one of the better ceilings among Royals pitching prospects.    Gomez has a quick arm that generates 93-97 mph fastballs and uses his 6-foot-3 frame to throw downhill, getting more than his share of swings and misses as well as groundballs. His curveball gives him a second plus pitch at times, though it's not as consistent as his heater. He needs to improve his changeup and employ it more because left-handers have pounded him on a regular basis.    Though Gomez has impressive stuff, he's still figuring out how to use it. He gets hit harder than he should because he doesn't command his pitches well, and his control regressed at the start of the 2018 season. If he can't realize his potential as a starter, he has the tools to make an impact as a reliever."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 50 | Curveball: 55 | Slider: 45 | Changeup: 50 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45  Tall, raw and projectable when the Mets selected him in the third round of the 2013 Draft, Meisner was in the midst of an impressive full-season debut when the A's acquired him for reliever Tyler Clippard ahead of the 2015 Trade Deadline. The 6-foot-7 righty struggled in his first full season with A's but has since rebounded after making an adjustment to his delivery. He pitched well in 2017 in his return to the hitter-friendly Class A Advanced California League, then built on that performance in his first Double-A exposure following a June promotion. The Cardinals acquired him from the A's at the start of the 2018 season for reliever Josh Lucas  Meisner's velocity began to tick up in 2015, with the right-hander sitting at 90-93 mph and at times bumped the mid-90s, but adopting a lower arm slot last season negated that progress while also changing the shape and angle of his curveball and hindering his control. Although his velocity returned in 2017, when he sat 90-92 mph and reached 95, Meisner was less efficient in using his height to create downhill plane to the plate. Meisner's curveball and changeup both project to be slightly above-average pitches, and he's also adept at mixing in a below-average slider.  Meisner shows the makings of becoming a back-of-the-rotation innings-eater with his size, durability and deep arsenal. Should he not stick in that role, the lanky right-hander could be an effective middle reliever with stuff that stands to play up out of the bullpen."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Slider: 50 | Cutter: 50 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45  Some pitching prospects begin as starters and get moved to the bullpen as professionals. Nogosek was a reliever for three years at Oregon, and a good one who saved 16 games as a junior before getting nabbed in the sixth round of the 2016 Draft by the Red Sox. He had pitched across two levels of A ball in his first full season when he was sent with Jamie Callahan to the Mets at the 2017 Trade Deadline for Addison Reed.  Nogosek has a deep repertoire, especially for a reliever, adding and subtracting to miss bats and generate weak contact. He'll throw both a two-seamer that sinks in the low 90s and a four-seam fastball that can touch the mid-90s. He throws both a slider and cutter, which might just be him changing speeds on his slider, very effectively and he'll mix in a fringy changeup from time to time as well. He tends to be around the strike zone, though his control does escape him from time to time.  While the right-hander was an effective closer in college, his stuff is likely short for him to handle that role at the highest level. If he can continue to throw enough strikes and miss bats as he reaches the upper levels, a future as a middle reliever awaits."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 50 | Run: 40 | Arm: 60 | Field: 45 | Overall: 45  Robinson batted just .202 with three homers as a part-time catcher in his first two seasons at Southern Mississippi, then worked his way into the lineup and hit .288 with seven homers as a junior in 2016. The Astros liked his power and arm strength enough to select him in the 21st round and sign him for $100,000. He showed off both tools by homering 15 times and throwing out 41 percent of basestealers in low Class A last year, then went deep four times in the playoffs to help Quad Cities win the Midwest League championship.  Robinson carries a lot of strength in his 5-foot-11, 225-pound frame and has bat speed as well, giving him impressive raw power. His right-handed stroke can get long as he takes very aggressive hacks, leading to questions about whether he'll be able to succeed against more advanced pitching. His below-average speed is better than most catchers and surprising for his size.  Though Robinson's arm strength is obvious, he had to work to shorten his arm action after entering pro ball. His receiving still has a long ways ago, but Houston believes his makeup and work ethic will allow him to become at least adequate behind the plate. If that happens, he could serve as a power-hitting backup in the big leagues."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Curveball: 45 | Slider: 55 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45  Stewart was a two-sport star in high school, one who could have headed to Texas A&M as a quarterback, but was signed away from doing so when the Twins took him No. 4 overall in the 2013 Draft. While things haven't been all bad -- he did reach Triple-A for the first time in 2017 -- it hasn't gone quite as well as planned. The Twins left him unprotected from the Rule 5 Draft this offseason and he went undrafted.  The hope had been that Stewart, as he focused on pitching only and matured, would find increased velocity and be a power-type frontline starter. He has both a four- and two-seamer, with the former topping out at around 95 mph and the other thrown with decent sink in the low 90s. He's been a groundball pitcher for much of his career, but he gets too reliant on the two-seamer at times. That's not just in relation to his four-seam fastball, but also in terms of how he incorporates his other pitches, a slider that can be above-average and fringy curveball and changeup.  As Stewart has struggled, invariable rumors of him returning to football have cropped up. He's committed to baseball and the Twins are hoping they can help him maximize all of his pitches and still reach his potential as a big league starter."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 45 | Run: 50 | Arm: 50 | Field: 45 | Overall: 45  The trade of R.A. Dickey to the Mets will forever be remembered as the deal that made Noah Syndergaard a Met, along with Travis d'Arnaud. It looked like getting Becerra as the third lower-level prospect in the deal would be a real coup as he raked in the Appalachian League in 2014 and then in full-season ball in 2015, but a shoulder injury in 2016 forced him out for an extended spell and his emerging power vanished upon his return.  Becerra will still flash plus raw power from the right side of the plate, but it hasn't shown up in games since before the injury and he compiled just 22 extra-base hits in 2017. He's long been an aggressive hitter who doesn't walk much, and his approach in some ways has gone backwards, with an increased strikeout rate. His arm in the outfield has bounced back and might be better than average eventually. An average runner, his instincts as a defender are fringy.  Becerra was added to the 40-man roster after the 2016 season, but he was removed last offseason. He wasn't taken in the Rule 5 Draft, so he can use 2018 to show that his pop can come back another year removed from surgery and that he deserves a spot back on the roster."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 35 | Run: 50 | Arm: 55 | Field: 50 | Overall: 45  The Giants tried to sign Howard as a sophomore-eligible in 2015, but he turned them down as a 31st-rounder to play for the U.S. collegiate national team and return to Missouri. So they drafted him again the following June and nabbed him in the fifth round. He responded to a high Class A assignment in his first full pro season by batting .306 and could emerge as San Francisco's best middle-infield prospect if he can handle the jump to the pitcher-friendly Double-A Eastern League that has stymied many of its hitters.   While Howard makes contact more easily than most hitters in the system, he'll have to improve upon his modest power and on-base skills to profile as a regular. He may have some untapped strength that could translate into double-digit power if he does a better job of incorporating his legs into his right-handed swing. He has average speed but his instincts help him play quicker than that on the bases and in the field.  Howard played solely at shortstop in his pro debut, split time between there and third base in the first two months of 2017 then returned exclusively to short. He has fringy range at shortstop but his solid arm helps him make plays. He probably profiles best at second base."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 40 | Run: 55 | Arm: 45 | Field: 50 | Overall: 45  Krieger was still working his way back from labrum surgery that had disrupted his sophomore year when the Indians made him their fourth-round pick in the 2015 Draft. He made his pro debut in 2016, earning Midwest League All-Star honors at Class A Lake County before advancing to Class A Advanced Lynchburg in late June. He continued to perform the following spring while playing for upstart Team Israel in the World Baseball Classic, though similar success would elude him in 2017 over a full season in Double-A.   Krieger, a switch-hitter, struggled offensively in the Eastern League, but his bat remains his calling card to the Major Leagues. He controls the strike zone well, albeit with some swing and miss, and utilizes a short, direct swing from both sides of the plate to generate line-drive contact to all fields. While he has some wiry strength to his frame and is capable of hitting the occasional home run, Krieger continues to offer mostly gap power. His above-average speed fuels his extra-base hit totals and makes him a threat to steal.  Krieger's wheels make him a rangy defender at the keystone, where his post-surgery, below-average arm strength is a fit. He does struggle to control his body at times, with footwork that can be inconsistent, but club officials expect him to make gains defensively as well as at the plate going forward."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Slider: 55 | Curveball: 45 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45    An Ontario native, Romano pitched one season at Connors State JC (Okla.) before transferring to Oral Roberts and serving as the team's closer in 2014. He signed with the Blue Jays for $25,000 as a 10th-round pick that June, but he missed the entire 2015 season while recovering from Tommy John surgery. He returned to the mound fully healthy in 2016 and impressed as part of Class A Lansing's starting rotation, his first work as a starter since 2013. He continued to make strides in the role in 2017 at Class A Advanced Dunedin, showing impressive bat-missing ability while making every start.    Romano has shown plenty of arm strength post-surgery. His fastball sits comfortably at 92-94 mph, with good life and some run, and reaches 96. He gets whiffs up in the zone with the pitch but also gets hit around at times, albeit while keeping the ball in the park. Romano's power slider gives him a second above-average pitch capable of missing bats, especially against right-handed hitters, whom he held to a .192 average in '17. Neither his curveball nor his changeup is particularly advanced, and he'll need to make the latter a viable offering to be successful against lefties at higher levels.    Most scouts think that Romano will eventually return to the bullpen given the proven effectiveness of his fastball-slider combo against same-sided hitters. But after making gains in his first two years as a dedicated starter, the Blue Jays plan to continue to develop him in that role."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Slider: 55 | Changeup: 40 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45  Gregorio helped the Giants win the Dominican Summer League championship in his 2010 pro debut and led the Arizona League with a 2.32 ERA the following year, but he has been frustratingly inconsistent since leaving Rookie ball. He was locating his fastball as well as he had in a while in Triple-A last year before his season ended in July with a suspension for testing positive for performance-enhancing drugs. San Francisco designated him for assignment in February to make room for Tony Watson on the 40-man roster.  As a starter, Gregorio operates at 92-95 mph with a fastball that plays up because his extra-long arms give him terrific extension and create a difficult angle when he keeps his mechanics in sync. His mid-80s slider gives him a solid second pitch, though he'll fall in love with it too much at times. He never has had great feel for his changeup and it regressed in 2017.  Gregorio is 26 and has never demonstrated better than average control or fringy command, so it may be time to make him a reliever. In shorter stints, he might have a mid-90s fastball and a sharper slider."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Slider: 50 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 40 | Overall: 45    While the Braves have some exciting young arms getting ready to impact the big leagues, there's another wave coming down below. De La Cruz has the chance to be a part of that with exciting raw stuff, though he is still in the nascent stages of figuring out how to use it.     The young right-hander, signed back in 2015, has moved slowly since signing, spending parts of two summers in the Dominican Summer League (2015-16) and two in the Gulf Coast League (2016-17). He has a power arm that is capable of firing fastballs up to 95-96 mph, though he is still learning how to consistently maintain that velocity. His slider has the chance to be at least average and can miss bats on occasion. He shows some feel for a changeup, but he'll need to work on making it a more usable weapon moving forward. Like with many young pitchers, command is an issue, but when he's down the zone, he's shown a propensity for generating ground-ball outs.     At this point, De La Cruz doesn't always repeat his delivery, which leads to the control problems and fluctuating stuff. He's still very much a project, but one who could end up having starting pitcher potential down the line."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 30 | Run: 40 | Arm: 50 | Field: 50 | Overall: 45  After playing second base as a freshman at Wagner in 2012, Dini became the Seahawks' primary catcher the next three years. He slumped as a junior and went undrafted, then rebounded in 2015 to win the Northeast Conference batting title and become Wagner's all-time hits leader with 245. Since signing for $1,000 as a 14th-rounder, he has been one of the most consistent hitters in the Royals' system.  Dini's best trait is his ability to make consistent contact from the right side of the plate, which produced a .308 average in his first three seasons as a pro. He doesn't try to do too much, spraying line drives to all fields. His approach doesn't yield much power -- most of what he has comes to his pull side -- and his ability to put the bat on the ball means that he rarely walks.  Dini is quicker and more athletic than most catchers. He augments average arm strength with a quick release and shows aptitude for framing pitches. He has a small build for a backstop and profiles more as a backup than as an everyday player."

mi_blurb: "Age 20, signed out of Columbia in 2013; destroyed Pioneer League in 2016 (.376/.436/.606) but was more human in Low-A in 17 (.259/.313/.394), gap power from the left side and makes contact reasonably well, more home run power should come eventually; former middle infielder is athletic for a catcher but still working on finer defensive points; has promise but a long way off. ETA 2022."
mlbp_blurb: "Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 40 | Run: 30 | Arm: 55 | Field: 50 | Overall: 45  Signed for $460,000 out of Colombia in 2013, Viloria went from failing to produce an extra-base hit in 45 games in 2015 to winning Pioneer League MVP honors in 2016 after leading the Rookie league in batting (.376), doubles (28) and RBI (55). He didn't make the same impact last year, though he did hold his own offensively and threw out 40 percent of basestealers as the youngest catcher (age 20) in the low Class A South Atlantic League.   Viloria has bat speed and a knack for barreling the ball from the left side of the plate. His gap-to-gap approach and relatively flat swing cut into his power, though he has the potential to produce double-digit home run totals. He needs to hone his plate discipline after posting career worsts in strikeout rate (20 percent) and walk rate (6 percent) in 2017.  A shortstop when the Royals first spotted him, Viloria still is refining his defense behind the plate but shows promise. He has a strong if sometimes inaccurate arm, has the soft hands to become a solid receiver and has impressed the club officials and pitchers with his leadership and English-speaking skills. He weighs more than his listed 175 pounds and will have to watch his conditioning to avoid losing agility behind the plate and becoming a baseclogger."

mi_blurb: "Age 21, fourth round pick in 2017 from University of Virginia; hit .280/.315/.343 with six steals, six walks, 12 strikeouts in 175 at-bats in NY-P; reliable contact hitter with good speed, strong track record with wooden bats in summer ball; often projected as a second baseman but held his own when given a chance at shortstop for Mahoning Valley; ETA 2021."
mlbp_blurb: "Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 30 | Run: 55 | Arm: 50 | Field: 50 | Overall: 45  Clement was a two-sport star as a New York prep, standing out on the diamond while also excelling as a hockey player. He focused his efforts on the diamond by heading to the University of Virginia and took full advantage of scouts pouring in to see first-round teammates Pavin Smith and Adam Haseley. That exposure, along with his impressive track record that included an MVP campaign in the 2016 Cape Cod League, endeared him to the Indians, who selected him the fourth round.  Clement has the offensive profile of a top-of-the-order table setter. He has excellent feel for the barrel and contact skills from the right side of the plate. He proved to be one of the toughest college hitters to strike out in the country throughout his Virginia career, fanning just 31 times in 841 plate appearances (3.7 percent). An above-average-to-plus runner, Clement does have some basestealing ability. Defensively, he split time between second and center field as a freshman and sophomore, moved to shortstop as a junior and then split time between both middle-infield positions during his pro debut. He profiles better at the keystone, where his average arm and solid range are better fits.   Clement doesn't have the frame or strength to consistently impact the baseball, and that might limit his ceiling to being a super-utlity type of player who mostly sees time at second. While he has the tools to offer plenty valuable in that role, it also would be unwise to bet against Clement, who has long been lauded for his makeup and work ethic, becoming an everyday player."

mi_blurb: "Age 23, signed out of Dominican Republic in 2011; switch-hitter with .277/.358/.440 line in High-A/Triple-A, 14 homers, 18 steals, 64 walks, 130 strikeouts; real pop from both sides of the plate showed well in power-difficult Florida State League; good batting eye, strikes out some but looks recovered from injury seasons in 15 and 16; problem here is atrocious defense, .891 career fielding percentage at third is unacceptable, .987 at first base isnt much better; I think he can hit but where do you play him? ETA late 2018; QUESTION MARK: stone glove."
mlbp_blurb: "Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 45 | Run: 40 | Arm: 60 | Field: 45 | Overall: 45  The way Urena, who signed with the Mets out of the Dominican Republic in November 2011, began his career, he looked like a future impact player. He hit so well in 2013 during his United States debut in the Gulf Coast League and again in the New York-Penn League in 2014, the Mets felt confident in double-jumping him up to the Class A Advanced Florida State League. Two broken hamates derailed him in 2015 and he didn't produce as he had in a return to the FSL in 2016. He did get headed back in the right direction with an All-Star turn back with St. Lucie for a third season.  Urena once again looks like his bat could get him to the big leagues. He is capable of driving the ball, finishing the 2017 season with 51 extra-base hits, mostly in the pitching-friendly FSL, and it's easy to see some of the 34 doubles he hit there landing over the fence as he progresses. He'll draw walks and he did make some nice adjustments at the plate last year, though he can get rotational and pull-happy at times, leading to an elevated strikeout rate.  The biggest issue is Urena's long-term defensive home. While he made some progress at third during instructs, and has played some first base, his defense has gone backwards as he's filled out. He'll primarily move to a corner outfield spot in 2018, where his plus arm should play."

mi_blurb: "Age 23, sixth round pick in 2015 from Loyola Marymount, hit .266/.316/.339 with 20 doubles, three homers, 20 steals, 27 walks, 55 strikeouts in 448 at-bats between Double-A and Triple-A; easy to under-estimate, old-time scouts would have called him an intangibles player; runs well, but throwing arm is nothing special and hitting power is below average; all that said, he is a very reliable defensive shortstop how outplays his mediocre defensive tools with positioning, instincts, and impressive reliability: has a .982 career fielding percentage at short; most likely a utilityman but might surprise eventually; ETA 2018."
mlbp_blurb: "Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 30 | Run: 50 | Arm: 50 | Field: 50 | Overall: 45    While there has been a decided emphasis on finding high-end high school talent in the Draft in recent years, that doesn't mean the Angels have ignored the college performer set. That's why they targeted Fletcher in the sixth round back in 2015 after a solid career at Loyola Marymount. The heady infielder has been as advertised, making the most of his modest tools to reach Triple-A in 2017.    Fletcher makes a ton of contact at the plate with a line-drive approach, rarely chases and while he doesn't walk a ton, he also rarely strikes out. He had a solid offensive season in Double-A in 2017 then lost his gameplan a bit when he was up a level and without power to speak of, it's important for him to stick with what works best for him. An average runner, he can steal a base and has shown he can play short, even with just an average arm and range, largely because of his instincts and good hands.    In all likelihood, Fletcher will end up as a utilityman, having already displayed he can slide over and play a solid second base. That's his floor. How much he ultimately can impact the baseball will determine his ceiling."

mlbd_blurb: "Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 40 | Run: 50 | Arm: 70 | Field: 50 | Overall: 45  Alexander, whose father played in the Minor Leagues with the Cleveland Indians, was high on follow lists after a summer showcase circuit that included both the Perfect Game All-American Classic and Baseball Factory's UnderArmour All-America Game. An uneven spring has tempered enthusiasm somewhat, though there are still tools to be excited about.    Alexander's carrying tool is his arm, which grades out as an 80 in terms of pure strength, though he'll need to work on accuracy with his throws across the diamond. He has good enough hands and range to stay at shortstop long-term. There are more questions about his bat. He does have some raw power and some bat speed, but there has been enough swing-and-miss to worry some scouts about how his bat will translate at the next level.    A team taking the South Carolina commit in the top four or five rounds will believe the hit tool will come with pro instruction. He won't get drafted because of this, but knowing he is 93-95 mph off the mound, albeit as a raw thrower, is a fallback."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Curveball: 45 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45  Undrafted out of high school because he had Tommy John surgery, Mercer pitched largely in relief as a freshman at Oregon, then moved into the weekend rotation behind 2017 first-rounder David Peterson. A strong Cape Cod League showing last summer catapulted him into the Friday night role for the Ducks, where he's had a bit of an up-and-down season.  At his best, Mercer stands out with his arm strength and power arsenal. His fastball will typically sit around 92-93 mph, but he can reach back for more, flashing a plus 97-mph heater at times, both on the Cape and occasionally this spring, and he does maintain his velocity throughout starts. His secondary stuff, however, has backed up some. In the past, he'd show a short, quick, deep breaking ball with late break at the plate. It's been more of a slurvy pitch this spring with more of a loopy break to it, leading to hitters laying off of it and sitting on what is a largely true fastball. He has a changeup, but doesn't throw it much.  While he does largely throw strikes, Mercer does need to refine his command within the zone. That, plus some effort in his delivery, has some scouts predicting a future in the bullpen, though with his ability to maintain his fastball, he could get the opportunity to start at the outset of his pro career."

mlbp_blurb: "Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 50 | Run: 30 | Arm: 50 | Field: 45 | Overall: 45  Huff led Arizona high schoolers with 14 homers in 2016 and was the first one selected in the Draft that June, signing for $225,000 as a seventh-rounder. He spent his first two pro seasons close to home while repeating the Rookie-level Arizona League, batting .330 in his debut and tying for the home run lead with nine in 2017. He has made good progress defensively as well and could wind up as the best all-around performer among Texas' stockpile of catching prospects.  Huff employed a more discipline, contact-oriented approach in his first year as a pro before becoming more aggressive and homer-conscious in his second. The strength and leverage he derives from his extra-large frame give him plenty of natural power, so he shouldn't have to sell out for home runs. There may be a happy medium where he hits .260 with 15-20 homers per year.  Though at 6-foot-4 he's bigger than desired for a catcher and he's still a work in progress defensively, he has the tools to get the job done defensively. While he needs to clean up his receiving, he's flexible for his size and scores well in Texas' framing metrics. He possesses solid arm strength but won't get the most out of it until he quickens his release."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 45 | Run: 35 | Arm: 50 | Field: 55 | Overall: 45  When Rortvedt was a Draft prospect at his Wisconsin high school in 2016, he was thought to be a potential all-around catcher in the future, one whose bat appeared ahead of his glove. After his first two summers of pro ball, he still has a ways to go, but it actually seems like his defense is more advanced than his offensive game.  Rortvedt looks like could be a plus receiver down the road and does a lot of things well behind the plate. He's very mobile with soft hands, receiving and blocking well, showing an ability to get really low. He has very good framing skills and is arm is solid average and accurate, allowing him to throw out 36 percent of potential basestealers during his full-season debut in 2017. At the plate, the left-handed hitter does make consistent contact, but hasn't shown the ability to impact the baseball on a consistent basis. He does have strong hands and forearms, but hasn't been able to incorporate what overall strength he does have to drive the ball.  Patience is always needed for catchers develop, especially ones from high school, as the added responsibilities can slow your progress. Rortvedt now looks like he at least has the tools to be a capable backup. If the bat can come around as some expected when he was an amateur, there's plenty of time for him to evolve into an everyday catcher."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 35 | Run: 55 | Arm: 55 | Field: 55 | Overall: 45    Rengifo originally signed with the Mariners in March 2014 as the Venezuelan showed improvement on both sides of the ball as an amateur. He spent his first two summers in Venezuela and the Dominican Republic before making his United States debut in the rookie-level Arizona League in 2016, then jumped to full-season ball in 2017. The Rays got him from the Mariners in August of that season, but his time with Tampa was short-lived as he was shipped to the Angels in March to complete the C.J. Cron trade.    The switch-hitting Rengifo has a short, compact swing from both sides of the plate, with feel for the barrel that enables him to produce consistent contact. He shows some pop from the left side of the plate, albeit mostly to the gaps, but offers little in the way of power as a righty, with very good plate discipline allowing his hit tool to play up. Rengifo's above-average speed makes him a threat on the basepaths, and he's improved his basestealing efficiency to maximize that tool.   Defensively, Rengifo has already played a number of positions, mostly in the middle infield, though he has seen time at third and even in the outfield. He has the range, quickness and arm for the left side of the infield and the Angels had him playing shortstop during his first season in the organization, though his versatility could come in handy in the future."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 35 | Run: 55 | Arm: 50 | Field: 50 | Overall: 45  Agustin opened eyes during his impressive professional debut in the Dominican Summer League, one year after the Nationals had signed him out of the Virgin Islands. He performed well in his first stateside action in 2015 between the Gulf Coast and New York-Penn Leagues, but has been inconsistent on both sides of the ball at full-season levels. Agustin did post better numbers during his second tour of the Class A South Atlantic League in 2017, albeit after a demotion from Class A Advanced Potomac.  Agustin's quick hands from the left side of the plate fuel his game as a slap hitter who predominantly hits the ball on the ground and sprays it from line to line. He's also an adept bunter and gets out of the batter's box quickly, utilizing his above-average speed. Agustin will never offer much in the way of power, but he makes enough hard contact to accrue his share of doubles and triples while contributing with the occasional home run.   A raw defender when he signed, Agustin was one of Washington's more improved outfielders in 2016 after making strides with his routes and angles to the ball. He regressed defensively in 2017, in turn raising questions about his focus and work ethic. Though capable of playing center field, Agustin profiles better in left, where his speed and average arm strength are both fits."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 45 | Run: 30 | Arm: 55 | Field: 45 | Overall: 45  Yurchak posted an .880 OPS as a Wake Forest freshman in 2015, outperforming future White Sox second-rounder Gavin Sheets, but opted to transfer closer to home to Binghamton. After sitting out 2016, he was a Cape Cod League all-star that summer and led NCAA Division I with a 41/12 K/BB ratio last spring. Signed for an over-slot $150,000 as a 12th-round redshirt sophomore last June, he batted .345/.448/.520 in the Rookie-level Pioneer League during his pro debut and had other clubs ask about him in trade talks.  An on-base machine, Yurchak has a pretty left-handed stroke and controls the strike zone exceptionally well. He's strong and could develop average or better power if he adds some loft to his swing, though for now he's content to hammer line drives from gap to gap. He's somewhat of a lefty version of Kevin Youkilis at the same stage of their careers, though the Greek God of Walks demonstrated more pop.  Yurchak will really have to hit, because all of his value comes from his bat. He's a well below-average runner and athlete who moved to first base after committing eight errors in 12 pro games at third base. He does have solid arm strength and Chicago hopes he can develop into an adequate defender at first."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 60 | Cutter: 60 | Changeup: 45 | Control: 40 | Overall: 45    Johnston broke out in 2016 in the California Collegiate League, showcasing the circuit's best arm and shutting down the U.S. collegiate national team for six innings in a June start. He began his junior year as a starter before being asked to fill Texas' void at closer and cashing in on his first two save opportunities. He then lost command of the strike zone and struggled before returning to the rotation. The Nationals made him their sixth-round pick in June, and he signed for slot value.    Johnston possesses a pair of plus pitches in his fastball and cutter/slider. His heater consistently sits at 92-94 mph and reaches 96 in most outings, while his cutter arrives at 88-90 mph with darting action. He also has a changeup that could become a serviceable pitch if he uses it more often.    There is a lot of effort in Johnston's inconsistent overhand delivery, and it in turn hinders his control and command. But with two weapons and a strong build, Johnston has the makings of becoming a reliever at the highest level."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 20 | Run: 60 | Arm: 50 | Field: 60 | Overall: 45  Learning to switch-hit as a sophomore at Sam Houston State in 2016, Johnson parlayed his new skill into a 46-game on-base streak. He ranked fourth in NCAA Division I with 33 stolen bases as a junior, establishing himself as one of the best speedsters and defenders available in the '17 Draft. After signing as a sixth-rounder, he placed second in the Northwest League in batting average (.329) and fourth in on-base percentage (.400) and steals (25) during his pro debut while playing for Class A Short-Season Salem-Keizer.    Johnson's best tool is his speed, which some evaluators grade as well above average. He hits the ball on the ground and uses his quickness to get on base, where he's a threat to steal. He covers plenty of ground in center field, where he also has a knack for throwing out runners with his average arm.    Johnson focuses on making contact at the plate, showing more feel for hitting and driving the ball a bit more frequently from his natural right side. He hasn't put the ball in play consistently as a pro as he did as a collegian, though he has retained his knack for getting hit by pitches to enhance his OBP. He needs to make more contact and draw more walks to become a true table setter at the top of a lineup."

"Scouting grades: Fastball: 55 | Curveball: 55 | Changeup: 40 | Control: 45 | Overall: 45         It looked for a while in 2016, two years after he was taken in the second round of the Draft out of the New Jersey high school ranks and signed away from his North Carolina commitment, that Gatto's career was in trouble. He struggled so much in his full-season debut that the Angels removed him from competitive pitching and sent him back to their Minor League complex in Arizona to start over. A year after that, in a story of resiliency, Gatto pitched his way from the Midwest League up to the California League by season's end.         Gatto made a living in 2017 getting hitters to beat his low-90s two-seamer into the ground. His curve can be at least above-average; it's a weapon he needs to commit to using as an out pitch more frequently in the future. That's especially important because he's yet to develop a consistent feel for a third pitch. While the progress has been encouraging, the right-hander will have to improve his control and command as he moves forward, issuing too many walks for a pitcher who doesn't miss a ton of bats.         The Angels will let Gatto continue to start in 2018 and he's plenty young enough to continue to improve. There may come a time, however, when the organization will want to see what the sinker-curve combination looks like coming out of the bullpen."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 30 | Run: 55 | Arm: 50 | Field: 50 | Overall: 45    It's getting to the point when the Cardinals draft a seemingly unassuming college performer in the middle rounds, it should be expected that player will completely outperform those moderate expectations. Edman is another example to add to the file, a 2016 sixth-rounder out of Stanford who played across three levels in his first full year, including Double-A during the regular season, then got moved up to Triple-A and contributed to Memphis' run to the Pacific Coast League title.    Edman is the kind of player whose whole is greater than the sum of his parts, one who can do a lot of things fairly well. He has a great contact-first approach at the plate and doesn't strike out a ton. The switch-hitter has the ability to drive the ball to the gaps, but don't look for him to hit many over the fence. While he has solid pitch recognition and knowledge of the strike zone, he's not a big walk guy and is aggressive in hitter's counts. He has outstanding instincts defensively that allow his solid range and average arm to play up, giving him the chance to stay at shortstop long-term.    Edman has made a beeline up the organizational ladder and is now close to knocking on the door. He'll keep playing shortstop primarily, though at some point expect him to start trying other positions on for size for an eventual career as a utility man."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 50 | Power: 20 | Run: 65 | Arm: 45 | Field: 55 | Overall: 45  Freeman opted to return to Louisiana State for his senior year after being selected in the 18th round in 2016. He immediately improved his stock by hitting .374 to capture the Cape Cod League batting title, and then followed it with a .315 average and 19 steals as a senior. He would ultimately sign with the Nationals for $50,000 as their third-round pick, though a minor injury from Freeman's college season kept him from making his pro debut.  Freeman is a sum of all parts player who knows how to get the most out of his modest tools. As an undersized right-handed hitter, Freeman focuses on making line-drive contact and putting the ball in play so as to utilize his plus speed. He has pop to the gaps but little-to-no home run power. He shows instincts, range and soft hands at second base, leading many to project him as an above-average defender at the position.   After sitting out his professional debut, Freeman will begin his career in 2018. His lack of impact potential at the plate limits his overall ceiling, though he does enough things well to conceivably reach the Majors in a reserve role."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 55 | Power: 35 | Run: 30 | Arm: 45 | Field: 45 | Overall: 45  Wherever Mazeika has been, he's hit. He parlayed a career .348 average and .469 on-base percentage into an eight-round selection in the 2015 Draft by the Mets. Guys taken that late have to prove themselves level-by-level, and Mazeika did just that, hitting over .300 in his pro debut and full-season debut in 2016. He kept on hitting and getting on-base enough to earn a late promotion to Double-A at the end of the Double-A season.  Mazeika has used a contact-first approach to hit .311 in his pro career heading into the 2018 season, while his strike zone discipline is also advanced, leading to a .413 on-base percentage as well. Right now he is all about line drives to the gaps from the left side of the plate, but he does have close to average raw power that his approach doesn't let him get to. The Mets will continue to work with Mazeika on small mechanical changes to try to tap into that pop a little, though he'll always be hit over power. He doesn't look pretty behind the plate and needs to continue to work on his receiving and game-calling, but he manages to get the job done, throwing out just over 30 percent of would-be basestealers in his career.  The Mets are confident he can stick behind the plate, and left-handed hitting backstops are always a hot commodity, at least as backups. If he can continue to hit and find a way to add a little power, he might outperform those projections."

"Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 40 | Run: 45 | Arm: 50 | Field: 50 | Overall: 45  Eaves was a decent prospect at his Texas high school in 2012, one who seemed likely to head to Texas Christian for college. But the Angels drafted him in the 16th round and were able to convince him to begin his pro career with a $100,000 bonus. A high energy grinder, he was sent to the Tigers prior to the 2016 season in return for Jefry Marte.  Eaves' first season with Detroit wasn't a good one as he struggled to adjust to Double-A pitching. A return to the level in 2017 led to better results and he even got some Triple-A time before capping things off with a very strong Arizona Fall League showing. Eaves has the ability to impact the baseball, but it has largely come without too much in the way of an approach.
